A CRITICAL PROBLEM FACING THE AMERICAN WEST, IN PARTICULAR THE SEMI-ARID SOUTHWEST, IS IN- CREASING ARIDITY AND ASSOCIATED RISK OF DROUGHTS, HEAT EXTREMES, AND WILDFIRE AS THE PLANET  WARMS UNDER RISING GREENHOUSE GASES. WE RELY ON EARTH SYSTEM MODELS (ESMS) TO PROVIDE FUTURE PROJECTIONS THAT HELP US PLAN FOR THIS CHANGING CLIMATE, BUT THE WIDE RANGE OF COMPLEX PROCESSES INVOLVED, MANY OF WHICH HAVE NOT BEEN WELL OBSERVED, LEADS TO CONSIDERABLE MODEL UNCERTAINTIES. NEAR SURFACE ATMOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR HAS BEEN OBSERVED AND CAN, IN SOME SENSE, BE CONSIDERED AN INTEGRATOR OF THE EVOLUTION OF THE VARIOUS PROCESSES THAT GOVERN THE  HYDROCLIMATE, SUCH AS MOISTURE TRANSPORT, SOIL MOISTURE, PLANT PHYSIOLOGY, AND EVAPOTRANSPI- RATION. ESMS INDICATE THAT WATER VAPOR OVER ARID/SEMI-ARID REGIONS OF THE WORLD, INCLUDING  THE SOUTHWEST, SHOULD HAVE RISEN SINCE 1980, ALMOST AT THE RATE EXPECTED FROM CLAUSIUS CLAPEYRON SCALING. STATEMENT OF THE PROBLEM TROPICAL OCEANS ARE KNOWN TO AFFECT SOUTHWEST U.S. (SWUS) DROUGHTS AND ARE THE MOST IMPORTANT SOURCE OF PREDICTABILITY FOR SWUS DROUGHT EVENTS ON SEASONAL AND LONGER TIMESCALES. PREVIOUSLY IDENTIFIED PATHWAYS LINKING THE TROPICAL OCEANS TO SWUS HYDROCLIMATE INCLUDE ATMOSPHERIC ROSSBY WAVE DYNAMICS AND ZONAL MEAN ATMOSPHERIC CIRCULATION CHANGES. THESE PATHWAYS ALL EMPHASIZE CHANGES IN ATMOSPHERIC CIRCULATION, THAT IS, TROPICAL OCEAN VARIABILITY AFFECTS SWUS HYDROCLIMATE BY DRIVING CHANGES IN ATMOSPHERIC CIRCULATION, AND THUS THEY MAY BE GROUPED AS CIRCULATION PATHWAYS. IN CONTRAST, CHANGES IN ATMOSPHERIC MOISTURE INDUCED BY TROPICAL OCEAN VARIABILITY, TERMED AS MOISTURE PATHWAYS, ARE COMMONLY FOUND TO BE SECONDARY OR NEGLIGIBLE. THE LOW FREQUENCY VARIABILITY OF NORTH ATLANTIC SEA SURFACE TEMPERATURE (SST) CAN AFFECT SUMMER US PRECIPITATION, WINDS, AND HEAT THROUGH ITS IMPACT ON THE NORTH ATLANTIC SUBTROPICAL  HIGH (NASH). WE WILL TEST THE HYPOTHESIS THAT THE NASH IS A SOURCE OF PREDICTABILITY FOR HIGH- IMPACT MULTI-YEAR TO DECADAL CLIMATE FUTURES IN HYDROLOGY/WATER RESOURCES, EXTREME  TEMPERATURES, AND COASTAL INUNDATION, AND THAT INITIALIZED MULTI-YEAR TO DECADAL PREDICTIONS CAN BETTER PREDICT THESE HIGH-IMPACT CLIMATE FUTURES THAN UNINITIALIZED PROJECTIONS. TO OUR KNOWLEDGE PREVIOUS MULTI-YEAR TO DECADAL PREDICTION STUDIES HAVE NOT INVESTIGATED HIGH-IMPACT CLIMATE FUTURES SUCH AS EXTREME PRECIPITATION AND HEAT, DROUGHT, AND COASTAL INUNDATION. IF OUR HYPOTHESIS IS TRUE, THEN THE IMPLICATION IS THAT WE NEED AN INITIALIZED MULTI-YEAR TO DECADAL PREDICTION SYSTEM TO MAKE SKILLFUL AND USEFUL PREDICTIONS OF HIGH-IMPACT CLIMATE FUTURES ON THESE TIMESCALES. AMONG THE MANY ENVIRONMENTAL LOADS ADDRESSED BY THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CIVIL ENGINEERS (ASCE) 7 STANDARD, WHICH IS THE BASIS FOR BUILDING AND STRUCTURE DESIGN IN THE U.S., BUILDING COLLAPSE DUE TO THE WEIGHT OF SETTLED SNOW, OR SNOW LOAD, IS DANGEROUS AND CAN BE ASSOCIATED WITH SIGNIFICANT DISRUPTION. THESE COLLAPSES ARE SOMETIMES DUE TO RAIN ON SNOW (ROS) EVENTS, WHICH CAN CAUSE A SURGE IN THE WEIGHT OF THE SNOWPACK IMMEDIATELY PRECEDING THE MELTING PHASE OR PONDING ON THE STRUCTURE DURING THE MELTING PHASE. CLIMATE CHANGE IS ANTICIPATED TO INCREASE THE THREAT OF EXTREME, SHORT-TERM SNOW LOADS AND/OR ROS EVENTS IN CERTAIN REGIONS OF THE UNITED STATES, DESPITE AN ANTICIPATED SHORTENING OF THE TYPICAL SNOW ACCUMULATION SEASON. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THE STATISTICAL DISTRIBUTIONS DESCRIBING EXTREME SNOW LOAD ACCUMULATION AND ROS OCCURRENCE EVOLVE IN A CHANGING CLIMATE ACROSS THE CONTERMINOUS UNITED STATES (CONUS). THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE NOAA'S CLIMATE PREDICTION CA- PABILITY BY IDENTIFYING AND CORRECTING ERRORS IN GFDL'S SPEAR FORECAST SYSTEM. THIS WILL  BE DONE BY COMPARING PREDICTABLE VARIABILITY IN OBSERVATIONS AND MODELS USING A RIGOROUS STATISTICAL METHOD THAT OVERCOMES MAJOR LIMITATIONS OF PREVIOUS METHODS AND PROVIDES A FOUNDATION FOR EVALUATING AND TESTING PREDICTION SYSTEMS ON MULTI-ANNUAL TO MULTI-DECADAL TIMESCALES. MAJOR ATTRIBUTES OF THE NEW METHOD INCLUDE THAT IT ACCOUNTS FOR CORRELATIONS IN SPACE AND TIME, HAS A SIGNIFICANCE TEST, AND APPLIES TO MULTIVARIATE SETTINGS. WE WILL USE THIS METHOD TO ASSESS HOW WELL MODES OF VARIABILITY ARE REPRESENTED IN SPEAR, CMIP6, AND LARGE ENSEMBLES. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL QUANTIFY THE FIDELITY OF INDIVIDUAL MODES, THE INTERACTION AND  FEEDBACK BETWEEN MODES, AND EACH MODE'S TELECONNECTIONS WITH REMOTE VARIABLES. OUR INI- TIAL FOCUS WILL BE IN THE VARIABILITY OF EL NINO AND NORTH ATLANTIC AND PACIFIC SEA SURFACE     TE

DURING THE COOL SEASON, SEVERE EXTRATROPICAL CYCLONES (ETCS) AND THEIR ASSOCIATED FRONTS CAN PRODUCE HAZARDOUS WEATHER EVENTS THAT INCLUDE HEAVY RAIN, SNOW, AND STRONG WINDS. SUCH EVENTS LEAD TO SIGNIFICANT LOSSES OF HUMAN LIFE AND PROPERTY AND ACCOUNT FOR MANY OF THE BILLION DOLLAR WEATHER AND CLIMATE RELATED DISASTERS THAT PLAGUE THE U.S. GIVEN THE DEVASTATING IMPACT ETCS CAN HAVE, STAKEHOLDER COMMUNITIES NEED ROBUST PROJECTIONS OF FUTURE CHANGES IN ETCS AND THEIR ASSOCIATED EXTREMES TO HELP THEM DEVELOP RESILIENT ADAPTATION PLANS. THE GOAL OF THIS WORK IS TO USE THREE GLOBAL CLIMATE MODEL LARGE-ENSEMBLES (GCM-LES) PRODUCED BY U.S. MODELING CENTERS TO DEVELOP NEAR-TO-LONG TERM PROJECTIONS FOR ETCS AND THEIR STORM-SCALE EXTREMES. OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW ETCS OVER THE U.S. MAY CHANGE IN A WARMING CLIMATE IS STILL HIGHLY UNCERTAIN AND VERY LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT HOW STORM-SCALE EXTREMES WILL CHANGE IN THE FUTURE. WHEN TROPICAL CYCLONES (TCS) MAKE LANDFALL, THEY OFTEN CAUSE BLACKOUTS THAT PREVENT A/C AND FAN USE. TCS ARE ALSO PRECEDED BY EVACUATIONS AND OFTENTIMES SEVERE TRAFFIC JAMS. THESE BLACKOUTS AND EVACUATIONS CREATE A HIGH VULNERABILITY TO COINCIDENT EXTREME HEAT EVENTS. CLIMATE CHANGE IS ROBUSTLY PROJECTED TO GENERATE MORE AND HOTTER HEAT EXTREMES AND MORE INTENSE TCS, SUGGESTING A GROWING HAZARD FROM TEMPORALLY COMPOUND TC-HEAT EVENTS. ACCURATE HAZARD ESTIMATES OF THIS EMERGING COMPOUND EXTREME ARE CRITICAL TO PUBLIC HEALTH AND POWER SYSTEM RESILIENCE WITH CLIMATE CHANGE. WHILE SOME EXISTING STUDIES HAVE ASSESSED COMPOUND TC-HEAT RISKS, THEIR APPROACHES NEGLECT DYNAMICAL INTERACTIONS BETWEEN TCS AND HEAT, LEAVING OUT PHYSICAL PROCESSES THAT MAY INTIMATELY SHAPE THESE SOCIETALLY-IMPACTFUL COMPOUND EXTREMES. THE GFDL SPEAR MODELING SYSTEM PRESENTS AN EXCITING OPPORTUNITY TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND QUANTIFY TC-HEAT EVENTS WITH CLIMATE CHANGE. SPEAR'S CURRENT SET-UP EXPLICITLY SIMUL

MARINE SANCTUARIES ALONG THE US WEST COAST EXPERIENCE A VARIETY OF BIOPHYSICAL STRESSORS WHICH ARE EXPECTED TO BE EXACERBATED BY CLIMATE CHANGE, INCLUDING EFFECTS FROM MARINE HEAT WAVES, HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS, AND SEASONAL EXPANSION OF OXYGEN MINIMUM ZONES. VARIATIONS IN PHYSICAL OCEANOGRAPHIC CONDITIONS ARE CRITICAL IN DRIVING THE ONSET AND MAGNITUDE OF THESE EFFECTS: FOR INSTANCE, THE STRENGTH OF UPWELLING IN THE CALIFORNIA CURRENT, THE VERTICAL DENSITY STRATIFICATION, AND THE AMOUNT OF ADVECTION OF SUBTROPICAL WATERS ALL PLAY IMPORTANT ROLES. THESE REGIONAL PROCESSES ARE IN TURN MODULATED BY MODES OF LARGE-SCALE CLIMATE VARIABILITY INCLUDING THE EL NINO/SOUTHERN OSCILLATION (ENSO) AND PACIFIC DECADAL OSCILLATION (PDO), WHICH OPERATE ON INTERANNUAL TO MULTIDECADAL TIMESCALES. ACCURATELY CHARACTERIZING THE RANGE OF CLIMATE-DRIVEN SHOCKS TO US WEST COAST SANCTUARY REGIONS IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE THUS REQUIRES ASSESSING THE IMPACT OF LARGE-SCALE CLIMATE VARIABILITY ON ECO

CENTRAL TO THE SUCCESS OF ANY EFFORTS FOR A CLIMATE-READY NATION IS HAVING CLIMATE-READY INFRASTRUCTURE BY TRANSFORMING THE ENGINEERING PRACTICE IN SUPPORT CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND INVESTING IN FISCALLY AND INTELLECTUALLY IN CLIMATE-RESILIENT INFRASTRUCTURE. TO HELP THE NATION ACHIEVE THESE GOALS, WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE SUPPORTING THE DEVELOPMENT OF A FORMAL COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE NATION'S LARGEST PROVIDER OF CLIMATE INFORMATION, THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) AND THE WORLD'S LARGEST CIVIL ENGINEERING PROFESSIONAL SOCIETY, THE AMERICAN SOCIETY FOR CIVIL ENGINEERS (ASCE). THE EXPRESSED FOCUS OF SUCH A COLLABORATION WOULD BE ADVANCING THE USE OF NOAA PRODUCED CLIMATE SCIENCE AND UNDERSTANDING WITHIN ENGINEERING PRACTICE FOR THE DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF CLIMATE-RESILIENT INFRASTRUCTURE, ESPECIALLY DURING THE DEVELOPMENT AND UPDATING OF ASCE CODES AND STANDARDS IN ACCORDANCE TO THE FEBRUARY 1, 2023 EXECUTED ASCE-NOAA MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING (MOU

CLIMATE CHANGE HAS TAKEN HOLD IN GULF OF ALASKA FISHERIES, WITH NUMEROUS FISHERIES DISASTERS OVER THE LAST SEVERAL YEARS, AND CONTINUING ECOSYSTEM CHANGES THAT ARE ALTERING FOUNDATIONAL RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN THE PEOPLE IN THE REGION AND THE PLACE. ACROSS THE MANY GEOGRAPHICALLY ISOLATED AND FISHING DEPENDENT COMMUNITIES WITHIN THE GULF OF ALASKA, FISHERIES  LOSSES MAY BE DEVASTATING FOR LOCAL ECONOMIES THAT LACK ECONOMIC DIVERSITY, MAINTAIN FISHING- DEPENDENT FOOD SYSTEMS, AND HAVE CULTURAL FISHING PRACTICES THAT CANNOT BE REPLACED. DESPITE THE  TREMENDOUS COSTS OF DECLINING FISHERIES IN THE REGION, THERE IS A DEARTH OF ADAPTATION PLANNING TO ENSURE THE RESILIENCE OF FISHING COMMUNITIES INTO THE FUTURE. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE CRITICAL NEED FOR FISHING COMMUNITIES IN THE GULF OF ALASKA TO FORMALIZE FISHERIES RESILIENCE STRATEGIES IN ADAPTATION PLANS, FOCUSING ON THREE OF THE MOST HIGHLY DEPENDENT AND DIVERSE FISHING COMMUNITIES IN THE REGION - CORDOVA, KODIAK, AND SITKA.

RISING SEA LEVEL IS ESCALATING THE FREQUENCY AND SEVERITY OF TIDE AND STORM SURGE DRIVEN COASTAL FLOODING ALONG THE ATLANTIC COAST OF THE US, AND WORSENING EXTREME PRECIPITATION INCREASINGLY COMPOUNDS THE FLOODING. DECISION MAKERS AND COMMUNITIES FACE COMPLEX CHOICES BETWEEN ADAPTATION STRATEGIES, SUCH AS GREY AND GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE, BUILDING RETROFITS, AND RELOCATION. FRAMEWORKS THAT CAN HELP TO ASSESS A BROAD SET OF OUTCOMES OF FLOOD ADAPTATION CHOICES ARE NOT YET AVAILABLE. EXISTING STUDIES PRIMARILY EXAMINE AVOIDED DAMAGES TO REAL ESTATE, WHEREAS DECISION MAKERS AND COMMUNITIES ARE ALSO CONCERNED WITH EFFECTS ON ECONOMIES, EQUITY, QUALITIES OF LIFE, NEIGHBORHOODS, ECOSYSTEMS, AND MULTIPLE CLIMATE RISKS. THIS PROJECT BRINGS TOGETHER INTERDISCIPLINARY EXPERTISE FROM TWO CLIMATE ADAPTATION PARTNERSHIPS, AND FOUR FRONTLINE COMMUNITIES WHICH SPAN THE NORTHERN AND SOUTHERN SECTIONS OF THE ATLANTIC COAST, TO CO-DEVELOP A TRANSFERABLE DECISION FRAMEWORK THAT COMMUNITIES CAN USE TO U

THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR RESILIENCE TO FLOODING AND INUNDATION ACROSS TWO DIFFERENT COASTAL ENVIRONMENTS: THE GREAT LAKES (GL) AND THE SOUTHEAST (SE). TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DO A COMPARATIVE STUDY THAT ASSESSES A STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT MODEL (SCENARIO PLANNING, SP) ACROSS DIFFERENT COMMUNITY DEMOGRAPHICS AND COMPOUND FLOODING ENVIRONMENTS. THE PROPOSED WORK HAS TWO DISTINCT OBJECTIVES: 1) IMPLEMENTING THE SP APPROACH TO INFORM INFRASTRUCTURE AND ADAPTATION DECISIONS ASSOCIATED WITH COMPOUND FLOODING IN FRONTLINE COMMUNITIES; AND 2) ADVANCING THE SP APPROACH TO ADDRESS ITS EXISTING BARRIERS AND LIMITATIONS.  SP IS A METHOD TO DESCRIBE AND INCORPORATE UNCERTAINTY INTO DECISION-MAKING THAT GLISA, THE GREAT LAKES CAP/RISA TEAM, HAS ADAPTED AND APPLIED TO A RANGE OF CLIMATE ADAPTATION PROBLEMS INCLUDING COMPOUND EVENTS. WE WILL PARTNER WITH ONE FRONTLINE COASTAL COMMUNITY IN EACH OF THE GL AND SE REGIONS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH GEORGIA

MANGROVES PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION AND ADAPTATION BY SEQUESTERING CARBON, SHIELDING VILLAGES FROM TROPICAL STORM DAMAGE, PROVIDING A HAVEN FOR JUVENILE REEF FISH, AND PREVENTING EROSION. UP TO 70% OF THE POPULATION IN THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC POPULATION LIVES IN AREAS AT HIGH RISK OF FLOODS AND STORMS, WHILE 95% LIVE IN AREAS THAT ARE THREATENED. COMMUNITIES LIVING NEAR THE MANGROVES DO NOT ALWAYS UNDERSTAND THESE ABSTRACT BENEFITS, AND SOME PEOPLE HAVE A NEGATIVE PERCEPTION, AND BELIEVING THAT THEY PROVIDE A BARRIER TO DEVELOPING BEACH TOURISM. THESE ATTITUDES, AND THE ACTIONS ASSOCIATED WITH THEM, ARE AN IMPORTANT CHALLENGE TO MANGROVE CONSERVATION.  THIS PROJECT IMPLEMENTS A RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED TRIAL TO ESTIMATE THE EFFECTS OF AN ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAM DESIGNED TO INCREASE UNDERSTANDING OF THE MANGROVES' FUNCTION IN THE ISLAND ECOSYSTEM. IT CAPITALIZES ON THE POPULARITY OF SPORTS IN THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC TO MEASURE CHANGES IN KNOWLEDGE AND PERCEP

COASTAL COMMUNITIES ARE CONFRONTING LARGE AND GROWING FLOOD RISKS. SMALL COMMUNITIES AND RURAL AREAS LACK LOCALLY-TAILORED RISK INFORMATION AND TECHNICAL CAPACITY TO DEVELOP INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS TO MITIGATE FLOOD IMPACTS. AS A RESULT, THEIR ADAPTATION NEEDS OFTEN GO UNADDRESSED, EXACERBATING DISPARITIES IN CLIMATE IMPACTS AND ACCESS TO RESOURCES. ENGAGING COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN MODELING FLOOD RISK AND ADAPTATION RESPONSES ENHANCES THE VALIDITY AND THE USEFULNESS OF THE PROCESS AND OUTPUTS. THIS APPROACH, WHICH WE REFER TO AS COMMUNITY-ENGAGED MODELING, CAN BUILD COMMUNITY CAPACITY TO ENGAGE IN ADAPTATION DECISION-MAKING WHILE FILLING CRITICAL GAPS IN INFORMATION ABOUT FLOOD RISK. THE OUTPUTS WILL SIGNIFICANTLY STRENGTHEN THE EVIDENCE BASE ON WHICH COMMUNITIES CAN DRAW TO DEMONSTRATE THEIR NEED FOR RISK-REDUCING INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENTS. THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS WITH FOUR COMMUNITIES IN HAWAI I AND NORTH CAROLINA, WE WILL INTEGRATE PHYSICAL, SOCIAL, AND ECONOMIC DATA TO ASSESS FLOOD RISK

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO INVESTIGATE THE EFFECTS OF SEASONAL TO SUB-SEASONAL (S2S) TIME SCALES ON THE COMPOUND FLOODING AND INUNDATION IN COASTAL REGIONS. WITH SUPPORT FROM VARIOUS AGENCIES OVER THE LAST 10 YEARS, INCLUDING NSF, NOAA, AND DHC, MUCH PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE IN THE AREA OF COUPLING HYDROLOGIC, HYDRAULIC, AND COASTAL (HYDRODYNAMIC AND WAVE) MODELS TO MORE HOLISTICALLY REPRESENT THE COASTAL COMPOUND FLOODING PROBLEM AND ESTIMATE ITS POTENTIAL RISKS ACROSS DIFFERENT TEMPORAL SCALES, ESPECIALLY IN THE LOW RELIEF COASTAL PLAINS OF THE U.S. EASTERN SEABOARD AND THE GULF COAST. BECAUSE OF THE COMPLEX FLUID INTERACTIONS IN THIS ZONE, FLOODING IN SUCH AREAS IS HARD TO PREDICT WITH STANDALONE MODELS THAT ARE OPTIMIZED FOR ONE TYPE OF FLOODING (E.G., COASTAL SURGE ONLY OR INLAND INUNDATION), AND THUS REPRESENTS A NOAA SERVICE GAP. FLOODING POTENTIAL IN THE COASTAL PLAINS IS EXACERBATED DUE TO THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE - SEA LEVEL RISE, HURRICANE INTENSIFICATION, A

SEA LEVEL RISE IS INCREASINGLY THREATENING THE COASTAL ZONE UNDER A CONTINUOUSLY WARMING CLIMATE, WITH MANY COASTAL AND ISLAND COMMUNITIES ALREADY FEELING ITS IMPACTS. WHILE SEA LEVEL RISE DUE TO ANTHROPOGENICALLY FORCED THERMAL EXPANSION AND LAND-ICE MELT INCREASES FLOOD RISK OVERALL, FLOOD RISK ON SEASONAL TO ANNUAL TIMESCALES IS MORE DIRECTLY CONNECTED TO NATURAL CLIMATE VARIABILITY  SUCH AS ENSO, NAO AND MJO. FOR EXAMPLE, DURING EL NI O WINTER MONTHS, THERE IS HIGHER- THAN-AVERAGE SEA LEVEL ALONG THE MID-ATLANTIC COAST DUE TO CHANGES IN REGIONAL SEA LEVEL PRESSURE,  LEADING TO ENHANCED COASTAL FLOOD RISK. ALONG THE SOUTHEAST COAST, THE ENSO SIGNAL IS WEAK, BUT THE CONNECTION TO THE PREVAILING ATMOSPHERIC CONDITIONS (SEA LEVEL PRESSURE AND WINDS) REMAINS  STRONG, FURTHER INDICATING THE POTENTIAL FOR SUB-SEASONAL TO SEASONAL PREDICTABILITY. ALSO, ENSO- RELATED SEA SURFACE HEIGHT ANOMALIES, ALONG WITH SHIFTS IN THE PREVAILING WINDS, INCREASE THE  COASTAL FLOOD RISK IN CA

ATMOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR IS THE FUEL FOR ALL FORMS OF PRECIPITATION. FORECASTERS ANALYZE THE DISTRIBUTION AND AMOUNT OF WATER VAPOR IN THE ATMOSPHERE TO ANTICIPATE RAINFALL EVENTS. RADIOSONDES PROVIDE A LIMITED VIEW OF WATER VAPOR. THEY ARE ONLY OVER LAND WHILE MOST WATER VAPOR IN THE ATMOSPHERE COMES VIA EVAPORATION FROM THE OCEAN SURFACE. SATELLITES CARRYING MICROWAVE RADIOMETERS WHICH CAN SENSE THE VERTICAL PROFILE AND TOTAL AMOUNT OF WATER VAPOR IN CLOUDY CONDITIONS ARE KEY TO FORECASTING HEAVY PRECIPITATION EVENTS. A CIRA TEAM LED BY THE PI HAS CREATED A MULTISATELLITE LAYERED PRECIPITABLE (LPW) WATER PRODUCT WHICH IS CURRENTLY BEING TRANSITIONED TO NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE (NWS) OPERATIONS. MODEL WINDS ARE USED TO ADVECT SATELLITE WATER VAPOR RETRIEVALS TO A COMMON TIME, CREATING A PRODUCT CALLED ADVECTED LAYER PRECIPITABLE WATER (ALPW). ALPW DEPICTS ATMOSPHERIC MOISTURE IN FOUR LAYERS (SURFACE- 850, 850-700, 700-500, 500-300 HPA) AND IS DERIVED FROM PASSIVE MICROWAVE R

GRIDDED OBSERVATION-BASED PRECIPITATION PRODUCTS ARE THE BACKBONE OF NOAA NUMERICAL WEATHER PREDICTION MODEL EVALUATION ACTIVITIES, GEOPHYSICAL AND ATMOSPHERIC PROCESS STUDIES, AND ARE USED IN OTHER FORECAST OFFICES FOR A VARIETY OF PURPOSES. OVER THE CONTIGUOUS US (CONUS) THERE ARE MANY RESEARCH-GRADE OBSERVATION-BASED PRECIPITATION PRODUCTS THAT OPERATIONAL CENTERS OR RESEARCHERS USE AS A DETERMINISTIC GROUND TRUTH (E.G., STAGE IV, PRISM, NLDAS2, MRMS, AORC). ALL OF THESE DATASETS USE DIFFERENT INPUTS, METHODOLOGIES, AND OUTPUT RESOLUTIONS, WHICH CREATES DIFFERENCES IN THE RESULTANT DATASETS ACROSS SPATIOTEMPORAL SCALES THAT NEED TO BE QUANTIFIED, YET THE ORIGINS OF WHICH MAY BE DIFFICULT TO DETERMINE. BROADLY, THE LACK OF UNCERTAINTY QUANTIFICATION AND INFORMATION CONTENT ON EXTREMES, LIMITATIONS IN DATASET GENERATION METHODOLOGIES, AND A LACK OF VALUE-ADDED DATASETS, INHIBITS ADVANCES ACROSS ALL USE CASES. AN IMPORTANT SOURCE OF SUBSEASONAL-TO-SEASONAL PREDICTABILITY IS PROVIDED BY TROPICAL INTRASEASONAL OSCILLATIONS, REPRESENTED BY THE WELL-KNOWN PHENOMENA OF THE MADDEN JULIAN OSCILLATION (MJO) AND THE BOREAL SUMMER INTRASEASONAL OSCILLATION (BSISO) THAT DOMINATE THE 30-90-DAY BAND, AND QUASI-BIWEEKLY MODES THAT DOMINATE THE 10-30-DAY BAND. IT BECAME INCREASINGLY EVIDENT THAT THESE TROPICAL INTRASEASONAL OSCILLATIONS HAVE DIFFERENT "FLAVORS" WHICH, BY DESIGN, CANNOT BE CAPTURED BY TRADITIONAL METHODS LIKE EMPIRICAL ORTHOGONAL FUNCTION (EOF) ANALYSIS. RECENT ADVANCEMENTS IN TECHNIQUES THAT EXPLICITLY TRACK INDIVIDUAL LIFE CYCLES (I.E., FROM INITIATION TO TERMINATION) OF LARGE-SCALE WEATHER PHENOMENA PROVIDE THE OPPORTUNITY TO BETTER MONITOR, CHARACTERIZE, AND UNDERSTAND THE VARIETY OF TYPES AND FLAVORS OF TROPICAL INTRASEASONAL OSCILLATIONS AND THEIR DIFFERING IMPACTS. THE DISTRIBUTION OF PRECIPITATION, INCLUDING ITS EXTREMES, IS CHANGING IN RESPONSE TO GLOBAL WARMING WITH DEVASTATING IMPACTS ON HUMANS, INFRASTRUCTURE, AND ECOSYSTEMS. IN ORDER TO PREPARE FOR, AND ADAPT TO, THESE EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS, QUANTITATIVE DESCRIPTIONS OF LONG-TERM CHANGES IN THE SHAPE OF THE INTENSITY DISTRIBUTION OF DAILY PRECIPITATION ARE NEEDED. CURRENTLY, MUCH OF OUR UNDERSTANDING OF LONG-TERM CHANGES IN THE INTENSITY DISTRIBUTION COMES FROM MODEL SIMULATIONS. THE SATELLITE RECORD IS TOO SHORT TO CAPTURE FORCED CHANGES IN THE INTENSITY DISTRIBUTION OF PRECIPITATION AT TIMESCALES OF A DAY OR LESS, HAVING STARTED ONLY IN THE LATE 1980S. INSTEAD, WE MUST USE RECORDS FROM OBSERVING STATIONS OF LONG DURATION, SUCH AS THE LONGEST RECORDS FROM THE GLOBAL HISTORICAL CLIMATOLOGY NETWORK DAILY (GHCND). THERE IS A CRITICAL NEED FOR ANALYSIS OF THE LONG-TERM CHANGES IN THE DISTRIBUTION OF PRECIPITATION WITH THESE OBSERVATIONAL DATA IN ORDER TO ADVANCE THE STATE OF KNOWLED

LONG-TERM MEASUREMENTS OF PRECIPITATION ARE KEY FOR UNDERSTANDING HOW CLIMATE CHANGE HAS ALREADY AFFECTED AND IS PROJECTED TO AFFECT SOCIALLY IMPACTFUL CLIMATE PHENOMENA SUCH AS EXTREME PRECIPITATION AND DROUGHT. WHILE CLIMATE MODELS PROVIDE INFORMATION ON CURRENT AND FUTURE PRECIPITATION TRENDS, IT IS ESSENTIAL THAT ASSESSMENTS OF NONSTATIONARITY AND RETURN FREQUENCY BE GROUNDED IN AND COMPATIBLE WITH THE BEST POSSIBLE HISTORICAL EVIDENCE. FINDINGS ARE SENSITIVE TO DEFINITIONS FROM RESEARCHERS IN TERMS OF METRICS CHOSEN, PERIOD OF RECORD, AND TYPES OF OBSERVATIONS USED TO QUANTIFY CHANGES. THE PIS PROPOSE A LABORATORY STUDY THAT PROBES THE AGING OF BIOMASS BURNING ORGANIC AEROSOL (BBOA) PARTICLES UNDER DIFFERENT ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS. THEY WILL MEASURE CHANGES IN BOTH THE CONDENSED PHASE AND THE GAS-PHASE DURING LONGER TERM PHOTOLYSIS AND HETEROGENEOUS OXIDATION EXPERIMENTS. THIS STUDY MAKES USE OF PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED FILTER SAMPLES FROM BOTH LAB AND FIELD MEASUREMENTS (FIREX) FROM 2016 AND 2019, EXPANDING THE CONTEXT FOR THE FIREX CAMPAIGNS. THEY WILL ALSO EVALUATE PHOTO-BLEACHING WITH SPECTROSCOPY, AND THUS PROVIDE A COMPARISON WITH ONLINE RETRIEVALS OF OPTICAL PROPERTIES. THE COMBINED RESULTS WILL PROVIDE A MORE COMPETE VIEW OF THE IMPACT OF AGED BBOA PARTICLES TRANSPORTED TO URBAN AREAS.

THE ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY GRC IS A PREMIER, INTERNATIONAL SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE FOCUSED ON ADVANCING THE FRONTIERS OF SCIENCE THROUGH PRESENTATION OF CUTTING-EDGE, UNPUBLISHED RESEARCH. THE CONFERENCE PROGRAM INCLUDES A DIVERSE RANGE OF SPEAKERS AND DISCUSSION LEADERS FROM INSTITUTIONS AND ORGANIZATIONS WORLDWIDE. THE TOPICS TO BE COVERED ARE FUNDAMENTALLY TIED TO NOAA'S MISSION, NAMELY TO UNDERSTAND AND PREDICT CHANGES IN CLIMATE AND WEATHER TO SHARE KNOWLEDGE AND INFORMATION WITH OTHERS. THE SPEAKERS AND DISCUSSION LEADERS FOR THE 2023 PROGRAM ARE MORE THAN 50% FEMALE AND INCLUDES ALL CAREER STAGES, INCLUDING EARLY CAREER SCIENTISTS AND OTHER UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS. 2023 ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY GORDON RESEARCH CONFERENCE IS SUBTITLED FUNDAMENTAL CHEMISTRY AND SOCIETAL CHANGES: SHAPING AIR QUALITY AND CLIMATE FROM THE MOLECULAR TO THE PLANETARY SCALE.

ATMOSPHERIC AEROSOLS AFFECT THE LIVES OF HUMANS EVERY DAY. THEY ARE A BURDEN TO PUBLIC HEALTH, AFFECT CLIMATE AND WEATHER, AND THEY ARE PRESENT AT ALL TIMES ALL OVER THE WORLD. AS OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE CHEMISTRY AND PHYSICS THAT DICTATES THEIR FORMATION, GROWTH, AND REMOVAL FROM THE ATMOSPHERE GROWS, IT IS AGGREGATED INTO MODELS FOR NEAR TERM PREDICTIONS FOR MITIGATING ADVERSE HEALTH EFFECTS AND LONGER-TERM FORECASTING THAT EMPOWERS DECISION MAKERS TO MITIGATE CLIMATE CHANGE. FOR THESE MODELS TO BE OF THE MOST VALUE, THEY NEED TO BE VALIDATED AGAINST MEASUREMENTS. SATELLITES PROVIDE AN UNPRECEDENTED OPPORTUNITY TO INCREASE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE ABUNDANCE, CHARACTERISTICS, AND LIFECYCLES OF THESE UBIQUITOUS PARTICLES BY PROVIDING MEASUREMENTS WITH GLOBAL AND ROUTINE COVERAGE. HOWEVER, THE QUANTITIES MEASURED BY SATELLITES ARE FAR REMOVED FROM THE MICROPHYSICAL, CHEMICAL, AND OPTICAL PROPERTIES THAT GOVERN THE EFFECT OF PARTICLES ON CLOUDS, RADIATION, VISIBILITY, AND HUMAN HEALTH.

AEROSOLS CONTINUE TO BE ONE OF THE LARGEST SOURCES OF UNCERTAINTY IN QUANTIFYING THE RESPONSES OF THE CLIMATE SYSTEM TO HUMAN IMPACTS. OBSERVATIONAL CONSTRAINTS ON AEROSOL PROPERTIES AND THEIR RADIATIVE EFFECT DEPEND CRITICALLY ON SATELLITE-BASED MEASUREMENTS. SATELLITE RETRIEVALS CURRENTLY DISCARD DATA NEAR CLOUDS DUE TO 3D RADIATION EFFECTS, EXACERBATED BY ENHANCED HUMIDITY, AND AEROSOL HYGROSCOPIC GROWTH. THIS CAUSES A SIGNIFICANT UNDERESTIMATION OF AEROSOL OPTICAL DEPTH AND THE DIRECT AEROSOL EFFECT, AND UNCERTAINTY IN THE ASSESSMENT OF THE ROLE OF AEROSOLS FOR CLIMATE. THIS PROJECT WILL CHARACTERIZE AEROSOL HYGROSCOPIC GROWTH AND ADVANCE AEROSOL OPTICAL DEPTH (AOD) AND OTHER AEROSOL PROPERTY RETRIEVALS APPLICABLE TO COMPLEX, HIGHLY 3D, CLOUD-AEROSOL ENVIRONMENTS. THE RETRIEVAL IS UNIQUE, BASED ON A MACHINE-LEARNING APPROACH THAT ACCOUNTS FOR BOTH 3D RADIATIVE EFFECTS AND AEROSOL HYGROSCOPIC GROWTH. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AN IMPROVED METHODOLOGY FOR A GRIDDED SNOWFALL PRODUCT IN THE CONUS, AND USE THESE RESULTS TO CREATE A NOVEL GRIDDED SNOWFALL PRODUCT FOR ALASKA. THE VERIFICATION DATASETS CREATED FOR THIS PROJECT WILL THEN BE USED TO EVALUATE A NEW UFS SEASONAL-TO-SUBSEASONAL SNOWFALL FORECAST PARADIGM. THIS WORK WILL FOCUS ON THE ROLE OF SNOW- TO-LIQUID RATIO (SLR) IN ANALYSIS AND FORECASTING. PRECIPITATION EXTREMES ARE A SERIOUS SOCIETAL PROBLEM DAMAGING INFRASTRUCTURE, THREATENING FOOD SECURITY, AND POSING HAZARDS TO LIFE AND PROPERTY. DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, FLOODS ARE INCREASING IN INTENSITY AND FREQUENCY, AND DROUGHTS ARE INCREASING IN INTENSITY AND DURATION IN MANY PARTS OF THE CONTIGUOUS UNITED STATES (CONUS). YET PRECIPITATION EXTREMES ARE DIFFICULT TO PREDICT AS THEY ARE RARE EVENTS OFTEN GOVERNED BY MESOSCALE CONVECTIVE PROCESSES INFLUENCED BY REGIONAL-GLOBAL ATMOSPHERIC DYNAMICS AND LOCAL FEEDBACKS WITH ANOMALIES IN THE LAND SURFACE. LAND SURFACE STATES (SOIL MOISTURE AND VEGETATION) ARE CONNECTED TO PRECIPITATION VIA A CHAIN OF LINKAGES THROUGH SURFACE FLUXES, NEAR-SURFACE METEOROLOGY, BOUNDARY LAYER CHARACTERISTICS AND CLOUD FORMATION. SUCH LINKAGES ARE PATHWAYS FOR FEEDBACKS, INCLUDING THE POTENTIAL TO ENHANCE OR ATTENUATE PRECIPITATION EXTREMES. LAND COVER CHANGES, WHICH OCCUR PRIMARILY THROUGH HUMAN LAND USE (LU/LC) CHOICES, AND ANTHROPOGENIC DRIVERS

LARGE AND RAPID SNOWMELT EVENTS CAN BE HAZARDOUS, PARTICULARLY WITH THE PRESENCE OF CONCURRENT RAINFALL. RAINFALL ON A SNOWPACK, OR "RAIN-ON-SNOW" PRECIPITATION EVENTS, CAN GREATLY INCREASE THE POTENTIAL FOR FLOODING, WITH LIQUID PRECIPITATION AND MELTED SNOW BOTH CONTRIBUTING TO RUNOFF, AFFECTING LIFE AND PROPERTY. FOR EXAMPLE, IN EASTERN NEBRASKA, A RAIN-ON-SNOW PRECIPITATION EVENT IN MARCH 2019 OCCURRED WITH 2-4 INCHES OF MEASURED RAINFALL AND THE RAPID MELTING OF APPROXIMATELY 8-12 INCHES OF SNOW. THE RESULT WAS CATASTROPHIC FLOODING, WITH ESTIMATED DAMAGES IN EXCESS OF $3 BILLION. DESPITE THE LARGE IMPACT THESE PRECIPITATION EVENTS CAN HAVE, RESEARCH INTO THEIR REPRESENTATION AND BIASES WITHIN NUMERICAL IS RELATIVELY LIMITED, ESPECIALLY WITH RESPECT TO THE ENERGIC FLUXES WITHIN THE BOUNDARY LAYER FORCING THE EVENTS. LESS ACCURATE PREDICTIONS OF THE CONTINENTAL UNITED STATES (CONUS) SUBSEASONAL-TO- SEASONAL (S2S, TWO WEEKS TO 12 MONTHS) PRECIPITATION THAN THAT OF TEMPERATURE IN MANY FORECAST  MODELS INDICATE THAT MODELS LACK NECESSARY SKILLS TO CAPTURE DISCERNIBLE LARGE SCALE ATMOSPHERIC CIRCULATION PATTERNS AND ASSOCIATED INTERACTIONS WITH LOCAL HYDROCLIMATE AND PHYSICAL PROCESSES THAT GENERATE PRECIPITATION WITHIN THESE TIMESCALES. SOME S2S "FORECASTS OF OPPORTUNITY" MAY BE REALIZED FOR PARTICULAR REGIONS IN THE CONUS AT PARTICULAR TIME PERIODS, WHERE THOSE ATMOSPHERIC TELECONNECTIONS DRIVEN BY SEA SURFACE TEMPERATURE (SST) AND CONVECTION FORCING STRONGLY INFLUENCE PRECIPITATION AND ITS EXTREMES (E.G., DROUGHT). EVEN IF GLOBAL MODELS CAN SKILLFULLY FORECAST THESE TELECONNECTION PATTERNS AT S2S TIMESCALES, THE PRECIPITATION FORECAST IS DEPENDENT ON VARIOUS PARAMETERIZED PHYSICAL PROCESSES AND SO STILL REMAINS PROBLEMATIC. IN PARTICULAR, LAND- ATMOSPHERE INTERACTIONS PLA

LANDFALLING TROPICAL CYCLONES (TCS) PRODUCE INTENSE WINDS, HEAVY PRECIPITATION, AND DAMAGING STORM SURGES ALONG THE GULF AND EAST COAST OF THE U.S. THERE IS GROWING EVIDENCE THAT HIGH ANTECEDENT SOIL MOISTURE CONDITIONS PRECEDING LANDFALL CAN MAINTAIN OR EVEN INTENSIFY TCS OVER LAND, SUSTAINING STRONG WINDS AND PRECIPITATION FURTHER INLAND. OUR PROJECT AIMS TO INVESTIGATE IF THE LIKELIHOOD OF MAINTENANCE AND/OR INTENSIFICATION OF TCS IS PREDICTABLE ON SUB-SEASONAL TO SEASONAL (S2S) TIMESCALES; AND ASSESS HOW THE REPRESENTATION OF PRECEDING STORMS IMPACTS SOIL MOISTURE BIASES AND MAY LIMIT THIS PREDICTABILITY WITH INCREASING FORECAST LEAD TIME.

A JOINT SCIENCE MEETING FOR THE TROPOSPHERIC EMISSIONS: MONITORING OF POLLUTION (TEMPO), GEOSTATIONARY EXTENDED OBSERVATION (GEOXO) ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION INSTRUMENT (ACX), AND TROPOSPHERIC OZONE LIDAR NETWORK (TOLNET) PROGRAMS WILL BE HELD AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA IN HUNTSVILLE (UAH) FROM MAY 1-5, 2023, THEMED "BUILDING THE PATHWAY FROM TEMPO TO GEOXO." THE JOINT MEETING WILL BRING TOGETHER THE TEMPO SCIENCE TEAM AND EARLY ADOPTERS PROGRAM ALONG WITH THE GEOXO AND TOLNET SCIENCE TEAMS TO FACILITATE THE COORDINATION AND LONG-TERM PLANNING OF AIR QUALITY OBSERVATIONS OVER NORTH AMERICA FROM GEOSTATIONARY EARTH ORBIT, WITH TEMPO SCHEDULED FOR LAUNCH IN APRIL 2023 AND GEOXO ACX EXPECTED TO LAUNCH IN THE EARLY 2030S. HOURLY TEMPORAL RESOLUTION OF BOTH TRACE GASES AND AEROSOLS FROM THE TEMPO AND GEOXO ACX MISSIONS ARE SET TO SIGNIFICANTLY ADVANCE OUR CAPABILITIES TO UNDERSTAND, MONITOR, AND PREDICT AIR QUALITY, WEATHER, AND CLIMATE OVER THE NEXT FEW DECADES.

THERE IS A GROWING RECOGNITION OF THE NEED FOR CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND RESILIENCE SERVICES AND AN EMERGING MARKET OF SERVICE PROVIDERS TO MEET THE DEMAND. MORE AND MORE COMMUNITIES AND BUSINESSES ARE WORKING WITH PRIVATE SECTOR FIRMS TO OBTAIN THE CLIMATE SERVICES NECESSARY TO INCREASE THEIR ADAPTIVE CAPACITY. IT IS CRITICAL TO ENSURE THAT COMPANIES DEVELOP THESE SERVICES USING THE VERY BEST, LOCALLY-RELEVANT, PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE CLIMATE DATA AND INFORMATION AND SIMULTANEOUSLY APPLY VETTED PRINCIPLES, STRATEGIES, AND APPROACHES FOR QUALITY CLIMATE ADAPTATION PRACTICE.  THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF ADAPTATION PROFESSIONALS' ("ASAP") CLIMATE SERVICE PROVIDERS ACADEMY ("ACADEMY") IS A COHORT-BASED, VIRTUAL TRAINING THAT GIVES PARTICIPANTS THE TOOLS THEY NEED TO DEVELOP QUALITY CLIMATE SERVICES AND HELP THEM SUCCEED IN THE RAPIDLY EVOLVING CLIMATE SERVICES MARKETPLACE. ASAP PILOTED THE ACADEMY IN 2020 AND 2021 AND IS NOW READY TO EXECUTE A NATIONWIDE VERSION

THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO INFORM THE TPOS OBSERVING STRATEGY BY ASSESSING THE FEASIBILITY AND USEFULNESS OF COMBINED UNCREWED SYSTEMS (CUS) IN MEASURING THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE AIR-SEA TRANSITION ZONE (ASTZ) IN THE WEST PACIFIC WARM POOL. SPECIFICALLY, THEY PLAN TO VIRTUALLY DEPLOY A COMBINATION OF UNCREWED AERIAL VEHICLES (UAVS, SUCH AS DRONES), UNCREWED SURFACE VEHICLES (USVS, SUCH AS SAILDRONES), AND UNCREWED UNDERWATER VEHICLES (UUV, SUCH AS GLIDERS) IN A COUPLED REGIONAL MODEL IN ORDER TO: 1. ASCERTAIN THE MAXIMUM SAMPLING RADIUS THAT ALL 3 COMPONENTS MUST REMAIN TO REALISTICALLY REPRODUCE THE ASTZ, 2. DETERMINE THE SAMPLING FREQUENCY OF (MAINLY) UAVS NEEDED TO CAPTURE ASTZ, AND 3. LINK TO REAL WORLD DEPLOYMENTS GIVEN FORECAST UNCERTAINTIES. THESE VIRTUAL DEPLOYMENTS WILL SAMPLE THE RANGE OF MJO AND ENSO PHASE COMBINATIONS CONFIGURATIONS.

DUE TO THE COUPLED NATURE OF THE EARTH SYSTEM, PRECIPITATION FORECAST ERRORS AT SUBSEASONAL-TO- SEASONAL (S2S; 2 WEEKS TO 2 MONTHS) LEAD TIMES ARE CAUSED BY A COMBINATION OF ERRORS/BIASES FROM THE ATMOSPHERE, OCEAN, ICE AND LAND ACROSS A RANGE OF SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES. UNREALISTIC SENSITIVITY OF MODEL CONVECTION TO ITS LARGE-SCALE ENVIRONMENT, AS WELL AS UNREALISTIC STRENGTH OF PROMINENT FEEDBACKS (E.G. CLOUD RADIATIVE, WIND-EVAPORATION), CAN LEAD TO THE INABILITY TO MAINTAIN SUBSEASONAL TROPICAL CONVECTION VARIABILITY IN FORECASTS. EVEN IF MODELS WERE ABLE TO PERFECTLY SIMULATE TROPICAL FIELDS, ERRORS IN THE SUBTROPICAL AND MIDLATITUDE CIRCULATIONS CAN FURTHER INTRODUCE FORECASTS ERRORS IN U.S. PRECIPITATION VIA INCORRECT TELECONNECTIONS. THIS MEANS THAT IDENTIFYING THE CORRECT COMBINATION OF MODEL BIASES THAT LEAD TO SPECIFIC PRECIPITATION FORECAST ERRORS IS INCREDIBLY CHALLENGING. THE MAIN OBJECTIVES OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT ARE TO UNDERSTAND KEY PROCESSES OF THE DIURNAL CYCLE OF RAINFALL OVER THE ISLANDS OF THE MARITIME CONTINENT AND TO ASSESS THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN SUBSEASONAL TO SEASONAL (S2S) MODELS' REPRESENTATION OF THE DIURNAL CYCLE AND THEIR FORECAST SKILL OF TROPICAL PRECIPITATION. CONVECTIVE ACTIVITY OVER THE MARITIME CONTINENT INFLUENCES A WIDE RANGE OF GLOBAL WEATHER AND CLIMATE PHENOMENA. DESPITE ITS SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN THE GLOBAL CLIMATE, THE MARITIME CONTINENT (MC) REMAINS SOMEWHAT OF AN ENIGMA DUE TO A LACK OF PHYSICAL UNDERSTANDING AND MODEL PERFORMANCE. THE MC CONNECTS THE INDIAN AND PACIFIC OCEANS, AND TROPICS AND EXTRATROPICS THROUGH TELECONNECTIONS. IT ALSO ACTS AS A PREDICTABILITY BARRIER FOR SUBSEASONAL-TO-SEASONAL (S2S) PREDICTION OF PRECIPITATION THAT DEPENDS ON MANY INTERACTING PROCESSES INCLUDING THE LAND-ATMOSPHERE INTERACTIONS, WHICH ARE CONTROLLED THROUGH SOIL MOISTURE, TOPOGRAPHY, AND DIURNAL CYCLE OF INSOLATION, AMONG OTHERS. MANY OF THESE PROCESSES, HOWEVER, ARE POORLY UNDERSTOOD AND INADEQUATELY REPRESENTED IN WEATHER AND CLIMATE MODELS. SEASONAL TO SUBSEASONAL (S2S) VARIABILITY IN TROPICAL PRECIPITATION AND MID-LATITUDE WEATHER IS LARGELY CONTROLLED BY THE EVOLUTION OF TROPICAL PRECIPITATION PHENOMENON. AT SUBSEASONAL TIMESCALES, THE MADDEN-JULIAN OSCILLATION (MJO) DOMINATES VARIABILITY IN PRECIPITATION. CLOUD SYSTEMS IN THE MJO RELEASE LATENT HEAT, WHICH PRODUCES A ROSSBY WAVE RESPONSE THAT PROPAGATES IN WAVE TRAINS AWAY FROM THE EQUATOR AND IMPACTS EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS THROUGH EARTH'S MIDDLE LATITUDES. HOWEVER, NUMERICAL MODELS OF THE ATMOSPHERE, INCLUDING NOAA'S GLOBAL FORECAST SYSTEM AND CLIMATE FORECAST SYSTEM, STRUGGLE TO DEMONSTRATE SKILL IN TROPICAL RAINFALL BEYOND ABOUT 21 DAYS EVEN THOUGH OBSERVATIONAL ANALYSIS STRONGLY SUGGESTS THAT THE MJO IS RELATED TO EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS IN THE UNITED STATES AT MUCH LONGER LEAD TIMES. ONE PARTICULAR DIFFICULTY IN MODELING THE MJO IS WHAT IS KNOWN AS THE "BARRIER EFFECT", WHICH IS THE TENDENCY FOR THE CONVECTIVE ENVELOPE TO STALL OVER THE MARITIME C

ACCURATE TC FORECASTS ARE KEY TO PREDICTING PRECIPITATION AT THE SUBSEASONAL TIME SCALE IN THE CONUS AS LANDFALLING TCS OFTEN BRING EXTREME RAIN, ESPECIALLY TO THE COASTAL REGIONS. GIVEN THE POTENTIALLY CATASTROPHIC SOCIETAL IMPACTS OF TORRENTIAL TC PRECIPITATION AND THEIR POTENTIALLY NEGATIVE INFLUENCE ON A MODEL'S SUBSEASONAL PRECIPITATION PREDICTION SKILL, IF NOT SIMULATED CORRECTLY, THERE IS A CLEAR NEED TO EVALUATE SUBSEASONAL TC PREDICTION AND UNDERSTAND ITS SKILL IN MODELS. WE PROPOSE A PROJECT FOCUSED ON THE SUBSEASONAL PREDICTION OF TCS AND THEIR ASSOCIATED PRECIPITATION IN THE CONUS IN THE UNIFIED FORECAST SYSTEM (UFS) AND OTHER MODELS. WE AIM TO IDENTIFY AND UNDERSTAND MODEL BIASES AND SYSTEMATIC ERRORS IN THE REPRESENTATION OF THE MADDEN-JULIAN OSCILLATION (MJO)-TC RELATIONSHIP, A KEY SOURCE OF PREDICTABILITY FOR SUBSEASONAL TC PREDICTION. EL NINO FORECASTS IN SEASONAL FORECAST MODELS STRUGGLE WITH EL NINO FALSE ALARMS AND OVER-CONFIDENT FORECASTS UNDER CONDITIONS OF RECENT WESTERLY WIND BURSTS OR AN EXTENDED WESTERN PACIFIC WARM POOL. THERE ARE TWO MAJOR CONTRIBUTORS TO EL NI O PREDICTION: OCEAN SUBSURFACE HEAT CONTENT AND WESTERLY WIND BURSTS. WESTERLY WIND BURSTS, WHICH CAN MORE GENERALLY BE DESCRIBED AS WEATHER EVENTS, PLAY A MAJOR ROLE IN THE SPREAD OF THE EL NI O FORECASTS. THEY INTERACT WITH THE UPPER OCEAN AT THE EDGE OF THE WARM POOL TO EXTEND THE WARM POOL EASTWARD THROUGH MOMENTUM, HEAT, AND FRESHWATER FLUXES. WE HYPOTHESIZE THAT FORECAST MODELS STRUGGLE TO CORRECTLY CAPTURE THE INTERACTION BETWEEN WEATHER EVENTS AND THE WARM POOL EDGE, WHICH LEADS TO OVER-CONFIDENT EL NI O FORECASTS AND FALSE ALARMS. SPECIFICALLY, WE HYPOTHESIZE THAT FORECAST MODELS DO NOT CORRECTLY REPRESENT THE UPPER OCEAN RESPONSE TO THE STRONG PRECIPITATION ASSOCIATED WITH WEATHER EVENTS AT THE WARM POOL EDGE. PRECIPITATION PROCESSES ARE MULTI-SCALE IN NATURE. A FAITHFUL REPRESENTATION OF PRECIPITATION IN A MODEL RELIES ON ITS CAPABILITY TO CAPTURE 1) LARGE-SCALE ATMOSPHERIC CIRCULATION PATTERNS THAT TRIGGER THE DEVELOPMENT OF A PRECIPITATING WEATHER EVENT SUCH AS CYCLONES AND THUNDERSTORMS, AND 2) LOCAL, SMALLER SCALE PHYSICAL PROCESSES (INCLUDING CONVECTION, RADIATION, CLOUD PHYSICS, AIR-SEA INTERACTION, ETC.) THAT DETERMINE THE LIFECYCLE OF A WEATHER EVENT THROUGH THEIR INTERACTIONS WITH LARGE-SCALE FLOW. IN THE CENTRAL UNITED STATES, WARM SEASON (MARCH-AUGUST) PRECIPITATION IS MAINLY ASSOCIATED WITH MESOSCALE CONVECTIVE SYSTEMS (MCS), A FORM OF "LAYERED" OVERTURNING CIRCULATIONS THAT IS OFTEN POORLY RESOLVED OR PARAMETERIZED IN A GLOBAL CLIMATE MODEL. THE FAILURE OF SUCH PARAMETERIZATIONS TO REALISTICALLY ACCOUNT FOR SCALE-INTERACTIONS, TOGETHER WITH MODEL INTRINSIC BIASES IN REPRODUCING LARGE-SCALE FORCING OF MCSS, POSES A MAJOR CHALLENGE IN OUR EFFORT TO SIMULATE AND

EXTRATROPICAL CYCLONES, WHICH MAKE UP THE MID-LATITUDE STORM TRACKS, ARE THE KEY DRIVER PRODUCING COOL SEASON PRECIPITATION IN THE CONUS. HENCE, BIASES AND ERRORS IN CYCLONE AND STORM TRACK PREDICTION, OR IN THE STRUCTURE OF CYCLONE RELATED PRECIPITATION, CAN GIVE RISE TO BIASES IN MODEL PREDICTED PRECIPITATION. S2S PREDICTION MODELS CAN HAVE BIASES EITHER IN THE MEAN CLIMATE OR IN THE PREDICTION OF CLIMATE VARIABILITY. HENCE, PRECIPITATION BIASES AND ERRORS OVER THE CONUS CAN ARISE DUE TO MODEL BIASES AND ERRORS IN: 1) THE PREDICTION OF CLIMATE DRIVERS SUCH AS ENSO, MJO, POLAR VORTEX AND THE QBO; 2) THE MID-LATITUDE TELECONNECTION PATTERNS ASSOCIATED WITH THESE CLIMATE MODES; 3) THE RESPONSE OF EXTRATROPICAL CYCLONES TO THESE LARGE SCALE TELECONNECTIONS; AND 4) THE PRECIPITATION STRUCTURE ASSOCIATED WITH EXTRATROPICAL CYCLONES. PRELIMINARY RESULTS BY THE PIS' GROUPS HAVE SHOWN THAT S2S MODEL SIMULATIONS EXHIBIT SEVERAL OF THESE BIASES. THIS PROJECT WILL DIAGNOSE EXTRATROPICAL CYCLON

THE GOAL OF THE TPOS2020 PROJECT IS TO DESIGN AN EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE BACKBONE OBSERVING SYSTEM TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE PROCESSES IN THE TROPICAL PACIFIC THAT ARE INSTRUMENTAL TO THE EL NI??OUTHERN OSCILLATION (ENSO) AND PROVIDE USEFUL OBSERVATIONAL CONSTRAINTS FOR PREDICTIONS. THE PROCESS STUDIES BEING PLANNED IN THE WESTERN AND EASTERN EQUATORIAL PACIFIC ARE INTENDED TO SHED LIGHT ON PHYSICAL PROCESSES AND GUIDE THE DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE TPOS. THE STRONG SEA SURFACE SALINITY AND TEMPERATURE FRONTS MARKING THE EASTERN EDGE OF THE WARM POOL AND EQUATORIAL COLD TONGUE REPRESENT DRAMATIC REGIME TRANSITIONS FROM THE OCEAN-ATMOSPHERE-WAVE COUPLING PERSPECTIVE, WHERE SHORT SPACE/TIME SCALE CHANGES IN THE BALANCE BETWEEN THE OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC BOUNDARY LAYERS PRESENT SIGNIFICANT OBSERVATIONAL AND MODELING CHALLENGES. THE EQUATORIAL UNDERCURRENT (EUC) BRINGS COLD WATERS NEAR THE SURFACE, WHERE THEY ARE TRANSFORMED THROUGH MIXING AND AIR-SEA FLUXES THEN EXPORTED TO HIGHER LATITUDES. THIS UPWELLING IS NOT ACCOMPLISHED BY EUC ADVECTION ALONE; MUCH OF THE CONNECTIVITY TO THE SURFACE OCCURS VIA TURBULENT TRANSPORT PROCESSES. PACIFIC UPWELLING AND MIXING PHYSICS (PUMP) IS A PROPOSED EFFORT TO DIAGNOSE THESE VERTICAL TRANSPORT PROCESSES IN THE EAST-CENTRAL EQUATORIAL PACIFIC. TO INFORM PUMP WE CAN LOOK TO THE EQUATORMIX PROJECT, WHICH TOOK A HIGHLY RELEVANT DATASET ON AND AROUND THE EQUATOR AT 140 W WHILE A TROPICAL INSTABILITY WAVE (TIW) FRONT WAS PASSING THROUGH IN OCTOBER 2012. THE EQUATORMIX CAMPAIGN INVOLVED INTENSIVE OBSERVATION OF THE UPPER OCEAN AND OF THE ATMOSPHERE BOUNDARY LAYER WITH UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. WE PROPOSE HIGH-RESOLUTION ASSIMILATION OF THESE EQUATORMIX OBSERVATIONS IN AN OCEAN MODEL TO YIELD UNDERSTANDING OF UPWELLING PHYSICS, MODELING NEEDS, AND OBSERVING DESIGN FOR PUMP. THE DA

THE INTENSE OCEANIC HEAT UPTAKE AND AIR-SEA COUPLING OF THE EASTERN EQUATORIAL PACIFIC COLD TONGUE ARE ENABLED AND MAINTAINED BY EFFICIENT, TURBULENCE-DRIVEN COMMUNICATION BETWEEN THE SURFACE AND THE SHALLOW THERMOCLINE. THE COLD TONGUE IS DYNAMICALLY SPECIAL: THE SHOALING THERMOCLINE AND RESULTING STRONG SHEAR BETWEEN THE WESTWARD SURFACE CURRENT AND THE SHALLOW EASTWARD EQUATORIAL UNDERCURRENT (EUC) RESULT IN FLOW THAT IS PERSISTENTLY SUSCEPTIBLE TO SHEAR INSTABILITY BELOW THE MIXED LAYER (MARGINALLY UNSTABLE FLOW). FISHES THAT REPRODUCE VIA FISH SPAWNING AGGREGATIONS (FSAS) ARE AMONG THE MOST VULNERABLE TO THREATS FROM OVERFISHING AND CLIMATE CHANGE. MARINE RESERVES ARE ONE OF THE MOST EFFECTIVE WAYS OF PROTECTING FSAS, BUT IT IS UNKNOWN IF CURRENT RESERVES WILL SUPPORT FSAS IN THE FUTURE. THE PIS PROPOSE TO MODEL CHANGES IN THE DISTRIBUTION, PHENOLOGY, AND METAPOPULATION STRUCTURE OF FSAS UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS FOR NASSAU GROUPER AND CUBERA SNAPPER IN THE REGIONS OF THREE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARIES: GRAY'S REEF, FLORIDA KEYS, AND FLOWER GARDEN BANKS. THE PIS WILL USE THREE CMIP6 CLIMATE MODELS TO ASSESS OCEANIC CHANGES AT SANCTUARIES UNDER TWO CLIMATE SCENARIOS. OCEANIC CONDITIONS FROM THESE MODELS WILL THEN BE USED TO DETERMINE THE SUITABILITY OF SPAWNING HABITAT VIA THE NON-PARAMETRIC PROBABILISTIC ECOLOGICAL NICHE MODEL. THE USE OF ARTIFICIAL STRUCTURES AND SOURCE-SINK DYNAMICS OF LARVAL DISPERSAL WILL ALSO BE EVALUATED. AN ADVISORY PANEL OF STAKEHOLDERS AT MULTIPLE NOAA PR

IN THE CALIFORNIA CURRENT, NORTHERN ANCHOVY AND KRILL ARE A PRIMARY SOURCE OF FORAGE FOR MYRIAD MARINE MAMMALS AND SEABIRDS, AND SUPPORT DEEPWATER PELAGIC AND BENTHIC ECOSYSTEMS VIA VERTICAL FLUX OF MATERIAL. ANCHOVY POPULATIONS IN THE REGION WERE LOW THROUGHOUT MUCH OF THE 2000S, RESULTING IN WIDESPREAD MASS STRANDINGS OF SEABIRDS, UNUSUAL MORTALITY EVENTS OF SEA LIONS, AND SHIFTS IN WHALE DISTRIBUTIONS. BEGINNING IN 2014, HOWEVER, ANCHOVY POPULATIONS SURGED AND RETURNED TO HISTORICALLY HIGH LEVELS BY 2016. DESPITE YEARS OF RESEARCH, THE MECHANISMS THAT FIRST CAUSED ANCHOVY TO DECLINE AND THEN REBOUND ARE OPAQUE. BY INTEGRATING EXISTING FIELD/SATELLITE OBSERVATIONS, SPECIES-SPECIFIC DIET INFORMATION, AND STATE-OF-THE-ART MODELING TECHNIQUES, OUR PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL EVALUATE THE BROADER OCEAN/CLIMATE DRIVERS CONTROLLING ANCHOVY POPULATION DYNAMICS ALONG THE WEST COAST OF THE U.S. (INCLUDING THE CHANNEL ISLANDS, MONTEREY BAY, CORDELL BANK, AND GREATER FARALLONES NATIONAL M

THE PROJECT ADDRESSES THE FOLLOWING QUESTION: HAVE RECENT, ACCELERATED CHANGES IN CLIMATE ALTERED WATER CONDITIONS AND HOW ARE THEY CHANGING? TO ANSWER THIS QUESTION, THE PROPOSAL AIMS TO ASSESS CHANGES IN PHYSICS, CLIMATE, AND BIOGEOCHEMISTRY ESSENTIAL OCEAN VARIABLES (EOVS) OVER PAST DECADES ACROSS NMS SYSTEM (NMSS) WITH A FOCUS ON EXAMINING PATTERNS FOR TRENDS, VARIABILITY, AND OCCURRENCE OF EXTREME EVENTS. THE GOAL WILL BE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SET OF INDICATORS THAT CAN BE USED ACROSS ALL SANCTUARIES AND MONUMENTS TO ASSESS CLIMATE CHANGE.

CLIMATE CHANGE IS CAUSING THE UNPRECEDENTED REDISTRIBUTION OF LIVING  MARINE RESOURCES, IMPACTING ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION AND PEOPLE LIVING IN MARINE-DEPENDENT  COMMUNITIES. THESE IMPACTS HAVE BEEN OBSERVED IN THE CALIFORNIA CURRENT - A DIVERSE AND  PRODUCTIVE ECOSYSTEM THAT PROVIDES IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR MANY MARINE SPECIES, SERVICES FOR  MILLIONS OF PEOPLE, AND HOME TO FOUR CALIFORNIA NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARIES (NMS).   IT IS UNCLEAR HOW ICONIC SPECIES IN THE CALIFORNIA CURRENT WILL RESPOND TO FUTURE CLIMATE  VARIABILITY AND CHANGE, AND THE SUBSEQUENT IMPACTS ON THE CAPACITY OF NMS TO MEET THEIR MISSION  TO CONSERVE, PROTECT, AND ENHANCE BIODIVERSITY, ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY AND CULTURAL LEGACY.   WE PROPOSE TO USE EXISTING DOWNSCALED CLIMATE PROJECTIONS TO  EXAMINE PREDATOR AND PREY SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS ACROSS THE U.S. WEST COAST AND THEIR CONNECTIVITY  AMONG CALIFORNIA MARINE SANCTUARIES IN RESPONSE TO LONG-TERM CLIMATE CHANGE AND CLIMATE EVENTS  SUCH AS MARINE HEATWAVES (MHWS). THE OLYMPIC COAST NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY (OCNMS) OFF WASHINGTON STATE IS EMBEDDED IN THE NORTHERN CALIFORNIA CURRENT SYSTEM (NCC), WHICH IS AFFECTED BY MAJOR CLIMATE FLUCTUATIONS, INCLUDING MARINE HEAT WAVES, EL NI O, CHANGES IN TIMING OF SPRING TRANSITION TO UPWELLING, SEASONAL HYPOXIA, AND OCEAN ACIDIFICATION. THE SANCTUARY'S 2020 CONDITION REPORT (WADDELL, ET AL. IN PREPARATION) IDENTIFIES UNDERSTANDING SUBSURFACE PHYSICAL OCEANOGRAPHIC CONDITIONS IN OCNMS AS A KEY DATA GAP. THE NEWPORT LINE OFF OREGON PRESENTLY REPRESENTS THE ENTIRE NCC FOR SOME ASPECTS OF CALIFORNIA CURRENT INTEGRATED ECOSYSTEM ASSESSMENT (CCIEA) ECOSYSTEM STATUS REPORTS. THERE IS A NEED TO ASSESS UNDER WHAT CONDITIONS SUBSURFACE WATER PROPERTIES IN OCNMS ARE RELATED TO WATER PROPERTIES OFF NEWPORT.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO CREATE USER-FRIENDLY TOOLS TO COMMUNICATE RELEVANT CLIMATE INFORMATION INCLUDING PHYSICAL AND BIOGEOCHEMICAL PROJECTIONS FOR TWO DIFFERENT NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARIES AND ENGAGE SANCTUARY STAKEHOLDERS TO CONSIDER AND EXPRESS THEIR CLIMATE CHANGE CONCERNS AND PLANS FOR MITIGATION THROUGH WORKSHOPS AND SURVEYS. IT PROPOSES TO ASSESS AND PRESENT INFORMATION FROM CMIP MODEL PROJECTIONS ON SPACE AND TIME SCALES RELEVANT TO NMS, SO THAT WE CAN UNDERSTAND THE IMPORTANCE OF UNDERSTANDING THE LINKS BETWEEN HUMAN AND NATURAL SYSTEMS AND RESILIENCE OF THE NMS MULTI-STAKEHOLDER GOVERNANCE SYSTEM TO CLIMATE CHANGE.

THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO EVALUATE EXISTING DATA RELATED TO CALANUS IN THE GULF OF MAINE, STELLWAGEN BANK REGION, INCLUDING INTERACTIONS WITH SAND LANCE, USE A COUPLED PHYSICAL-BIOLOGICAL MODEL TO DETERMINE UPSTREAM INFLUENCES, INVESTIGATE THEIR POTENTIAL PREDICTIVE SKILL IN TERMS OF SUPPLY, SPATIAL SYNCHRONY OF POPULATIONS, AND CLIMATE-RELATED DRIVERS. THE PROPOSED WORK INCLUDES: 1) MODELING THE INFLUENCES OF THE MAINE COASTAL CURRENT TRACK AND WILKINSON BASIN AS SOURCES OF CALANUS SUPPLY TO SBNMS; 2) MODELING THE INTERACTIONS AMONG CALANUS AND SAND LANCE; 3) DEVELOPING AN INTERACTIVE TOOL PROVIDING ZOOPLANKTON AND SAND LANCE FORECASTS; AND 4) IDENTIFYING KEY DATA GAPS THAT NEED TO BE FILLED.

FISHES THAT REPRODUCE VIA FISH SPAWNING AGGREGATIONS (FSAS) ARE AMONG THE MOST VULNERABLE TO THREATS FROM OVERFISHING AND CLIMATE CHANGE. MARINE RESERVES ARE ONE OF THE MOST EFFECTIVE WAYS OF PROTECTING FSAS, BUT IT IS UNKNOWN IF CURRENT RESERVES WILL SUPPORT FSAS IN THE FUTURE. THE PIS PROPOSE TO MODEL CHANGES IN THE DISTRIBUTION, PHENOLOGY, AND METAPOPULATION STRUCTURE OF FSAS UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS FOR NASSAU GROUPER AND CUBERA SNAPPER IN THE REGIONS OF THREE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARIES: GRAY'S REEF, FLORIDA KEYS, AND FLOWER GARDEN BANKS. THE PIS WILL USE THREE CMIP6 CLIMATE MODELS TO ASSESS OCEANIC CHANGES AT SANCTUARIES UNDER TWO CLIMATE SCENARIOS. OCEANIC CONDITIONS FROM THESE MODELS WILL THEN BE USED TO DETERMINE THE SUITABILITY OF SPAWNING HABITAT VIA THE NON-PARAMETRIC PROBABILISTIC ECOLOGICAL NICHE MODEL. THE USE OF ARTIFICIAL STRUCTURES AND SOURCE-SINK DYNAMICS OF LARVAL DISPERSAL WILL ALSO BE EVALUATED. AN ADVISORY PANEL OF STAKEHOLDERS AT MULTIPLE NOAA PR

THE CLIMATE OF THE SOUTHWEST HAS EXPERIENCED MORE THAN TWO DECADES OF DROUGHT, PROMPTING WIDESPREAD CONCERN ABOUT THE ONSET OF THE SHIFT TO A HOTTER AND DRIER REGION THAT CLIMATE MODELS HAVE LONG PREDICTED. THE CURRENT DRYING OF THE REGION IS BEING DRIVEN PRIMARILY BY THE LONG-TERM WARMING TREND, ALTHOUGH THE REGION HAS A HIGHLY VARIABLE CLIMATE THAT INVOLVES HOT AND DRY PERIODS INTERMINGLED WITH RELATIVELY COOLER AND WETTER CONDITIONS. THE COMBINED IMPACTS OF INCREASING ARIDITY AND HIGH VARIABILITY HAVE CREATED A CHALLENGING CONTEXT IN WHICH TO PLAN FOR AND IMPLEMENT ADAPTATION STRATEGIES DESIGNED TO ENSURE THE LONG-TERM RESILIENCE OF SOUTHWEST SOCIAL-ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS. ADDING COMPLEXITY TO THE ADAPTATION CHALLENGES IN THE SOUTHWEST, MANY OF THE SOCIAL AND CULTURAL SYSTEMS THAT HAVE FOSTERED THE POPULATION GROWTH AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF THE REGION ARE UNSUSTAINABLE, INEQUITABLE, AND UNJUST. AS A RESULT, THE 2020S ARE PROVING TO BE A MOMENTOUS PERIOD IN THE EVOLUTION OF THE SOUTHW

CALIFORNIA AND NEVADA HAVE MADE SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS IN ADDRESSING CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS TO THEIR STATE AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES, BUT BOTH STATES REMAIN VULNERABLE TO CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS. AMONG THESE ARE PUBLIC HEALTH THREATS FROM EXTREME HEAT AND WILDFIRE SMOKE, IMPACTS ON WATER RESOURCES FROM EXTENDED DROUGHT, REDUCED SNOWPACK, AND EXTREME PRECIPITATION EVENTS, AND IN CALIFORNIA, FLOODING, BEACH EROSION AND DEGRADATION OF COASTAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND COMMUNITIES. CNAP, IN RESPONSE TO THESE CHALLENGES, PROPOSES A COMMUNITY-FOCUSED PORTFOLIO OF RESEARCH, ENGAGEMENT, AND WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT TO BE CONDUCTED BY A RENEWED TEAM OF CALIFORNIA AND NEVADA SOCIAL AND PHYSICAL SCIENTISTS. THE WORK PROPOSED EMPHASIZES PARTNERSHIPS AND SUPPORTING FRONTLINE COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE BEEN AND ARE IMPACTED BY SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL INEQUITIES. ISLAND COMMUNITIES SUCH AS THE US TERRITORIES OF THE VIRGIN ISLANDS (USVI) AND PUERTO RICO (PR) ARE PROFOUNDLY IMPACTED BY CLIMATE EXTREMES, WHICH ARE COMPOUNDED BY THEIR GEOGRAPHIC ISOLATION THAT DISRUPTS SUPPLY CHAINS AND EMERGENCY RESPONSES. THESE COMMUNITIES ARE ALSO HINDERED BY A COMPLEX GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE COMPOSED OF LAYERS OF FEDERAL AND TERRITORIAL BUREAUCRACIES FREQUENTLY LEADING TO INEFFECTIVE DECISIONS. THE PROPOSED WOK WILL INVESTIGATE THE GAS AND PARTICLE PHASE ORGANIC COMPOSITION OF SMOKE FROM WUI FIRES, INCLUDING STRUCTURES, AND SMOKE ARRIVING IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA THAT HAS BEEN SUBJECT TO VARIOUS LEVELS OF AGING. BY COLLECTING CONTINUOUS GAS AND PARTICLE MEASUREMENTS USING IN-SITU LABORATORY-BASED INSTRUMENTATION RESEARCHERS PROPOSE TO STUDY THE DYNAMICALLY CHANGING COMPOSITION OF WILDFIRE SMOKE IN A HIGHLY POPULATED URBAN REGION DURING TWO FIRE SEASONS. THE WORK WILL ALSO MEASURE STRUCTURE FIRES EMISSIONS AND DETERMINE EMISSION FACTORS (EF'S) THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH AN ONGOING STUDY OF STRUCTURE COMBUSTION AT NIST FUNDED BY CALFIRE.

THE PROPOSED WOK WILL INVESTIGATE THE GAS AND PARTICLE PHASE ORGANIC COMPOSITION OF SMOKE FROM WUI FIRES, INCLUDING STRUCTURES, AND SMOKE ARRIVING IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA THAT HAS BEEN SUBJECT TO VARIOUS LEVELS OF AGING. THE PROPOSED WORK AIMS TO USE COMPREHENSIVE TRACE GAS AND AEROSOL MEASUREMENTS MADE FROM SATELLITE REMOTE SENSING INSTRUMENTS TO STUDY THE COMPOSITION OF WILDFIRE EMISSIONS, HOW THESE EVOLVE OVER THE COURSE OF INDIVIDUAL WILDFIRES, AND DEPEND ON FIRE RADIATIVE POWER. THE WORK ALSO AIMS TO STUDY HOW SENSITIVE THE WILDFIRE PLUME COMPOSITION SENSED FROM SPACE IS TO RETRIEVAL BIASES AND HOW THESE BIASES AFFECT OUR ANALYSIS OF THE EVOLUTION OF WILDFIRE EMISSIONS. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY COMPARING THE RESULTS FROM THE SATELLITE DATA ANALYSIS WITH DATA FROM FIREX-AQ AND OTHER FIELD STUDIES AND ULTIMATELY AIM TO DEVELOP A SIMPLE PARAMETERIZATION THAT CALCULATES THE GAS-PHASE AND AEROSOL COMPOSITION OF WILDFIRE EMISSIONS BASED ON PARAMETERS THAT CAN BE SENSED FROM SPACE. THE WORK WILL BE CARRIED OUT A THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, AND IS ENTIRELY COMPUTER BASED.

THE PROPOSED WORK AIMS TO STUDY THE EMISSIONS OF TRACE GASES AND PARTICLES FROM STRUCTURAL FIRES REPRESENTATIVE OF THOSE FOUND IN WILDLAND URBAN INTERFACE REGIONS. THESE EMISSIONS ARE VERY POORLY UNDERSTOOD WHEN COMPARED TO THOSE FROM WILDFIRES AND HENCE THE WORK ALIGNS STRONGLY WITH TWO OF THE TOPICS IDENTIFIED IN THE FY22 AC4 CALL ON 'FIRE AND SMOKE AT THE WILDLAND URBAN INTERFACE': (I) 'INVESTIGATION OF EMISSION FACTORS OF FIRES THAT INCLUDE HOUSEHOLD MATERIALS' AND (II) 'ANALYSIS OF WILDLAND FIRE SMOKE IMPACTS ON URBAN AREAS AND FIRES AT THE WILDLAND URBAN INTERFACE.' THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN EMISSION FACTOR DATASET AND AN EMISSIONS INVENTORY FOR STRUCTURAL MATERIALS WILL HELP ELUCIDATE THE ROLE OF WUI-RELATED STRUCTURAL FIRES ON THE TOTAL EMISSIONS FROM WILDLAND FIRES AND SUBSEQUENTLY ON URBAN AND REGIONAL AIR QUALITY. THE WORK INVOLVES SYSTEMATIC SET OF LABORATORY MEASUREMENTS AT DIFFERENT SCALES AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY AND NIST.

THE PROPOSED WORK IS FOCUSED ON IMPROVING THE CHARACTERIZATION OF SMOKE PLUMES FROM SENSORS ON GEOSTATIONARY PLATFORMS; THE DEVELOPMENT OF SATELLITE-BASED SMOKE PRODUCTS THAT CAN PROVIDE INSIGHTS INTO SMOKE SPREAD AND ITS CHEMICAL EVOLUTION AND IMPACTS IS ONE OF NOAA'S MISSION AREAS. IMPROVED CHARACTERIZATION OF BIOMASS BURNING EMISSIONS ADDRESSES NOAA'S LONG-TERM GOALS FOR IMPROVING UNDERSTANDING OF THE CHANGING CLIMATE SYSTEM. THE WORK WILL BE CARRIED OUT IN COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY AND IS ENTIRELY COMPUTER BASED.

THIS PROPOSAL, ENTITLED A NORTHEAST SAFE AND THRIVING FOR ALL (NEST), WILL CONVENE RIGHTS HOLDERS1 AND STAKEHOLDERS TO SURFACE RESEARCH QUESTIONS AND STRATEGIES THAT CAN PROMOTE REGIONAL, INTEGRATED ADAPTATION. FIRST, WE WILL REVIEW THE EXTENT TO WHICH CLIMATE ADAPTATION RESEARCH, POLICY, PLANS, AND PROJECTS IN THE REGION ADDRESS CENTRAL CONCERNS OF EQUITY UNDER CLIMATE MIGRATION.  SECOND, WE WILL BRING TOGETHER EXISTING SUBREGIONAL NETWORKS IN THE VERMONT AND NEW HAMPSHIRE UPPER VALLEY, COASTAL MAINE AND NEW HAMPSHIRE, AND RUSTBELT CITIES IN UPSTATE NEW YORK. SUBREGIONAL CONVENINGS WILL SURFACE (A) HOW SOCIAL AND CULTURAL FACTORS SHAPE BELIEFS AND REACTIONS TO PLANNING EFFORTS FOR ADAPTATION AND CLIMATE MIGRATION; (B) HOW GOVERNANCE AND CAPACITY DEFICITS IMPEDE PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION AND HOW THESE CONSTRAINTS MAY BE ADDRESSED; AND (C) WHICH ENTITIES SHOULD BE CENTERED IN A REGIONAL ADAPTATION NETWORK THAT TAKES IN-MIGRATION SERIOUSLY. THIRD, WE WILL PARTNER WITH ANTIOCH UNI

SEVERAL SOLAR INTERVENTION METHODS HAVE BEEN PROPOSED TO MEDIATE ANTHROPOGENIC GLOBAL WARMING, INCLUDING MARINE CLOUD BRIGHTENING (MCB). MCB INVOLVES ENHANCING EARTH'S ALBEDO BY CREATING A LAYER OF REFLECTIVE AEROSOLS IN THE STRATOSPHERE OR BY SEEDING THE MARITIME STRATOCUMULUS CLOUDS, RESULTING IN MORE REFLECTION OF INCOMING SOLAR RADIATION. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS AND COMPARE THE IMPACTS OF THE TWO DIFFERENT SOLAR INTERVENTION STRATEGIES USING THE MEDIUM ENSEMBLES OF SIMULATIONS CARRIED OUT WITH THE COMMUNITY EARTH SYSTEM MODEL, VERSION 2 (CESM2) WITH STRATOSPHERIC AEROSOL INJECTIONS AND MCB. A MEDIUM ENSEMBLE OF CESM2 SIMULATIONS WITH SAI CONTROLLED BY A FEEDBACK ALGORITHM HAS RECENTLY BEEN CARRIED OUT BY MEMBERS OF THE PROPOSAL TEAM. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A SIMILAR MEDIUM ENSEMBLE OF SIMULATIONS, UTILIZING MCB INSTEAD OF SAI, RESULTING IN THE FIRST ENSEMBLE OF SIMULATIONS WITH STRATEGICALLY APPLIED MCB EVER PRODUCED. STRATOSPHERIC SULFATE AEROSOL INJECTION (SAI) DESCRIBES CREATING A LAYER OF HIGHLY REFLECTIVE AEROSOLS IN THE STRATOSPHERE, COOLING THE PLANET. NEARLY ALL OF THE AVAILABLE INFORMATION ABOUT SAI IS BASED ON GLOBAL-SCALE CLIMATE MODELS WITH GRID RESOLUTIONS OF 50-100 KM. THERE IS PRESENTLY NO RELIABLE METHOD OF OBTAINING LOCAL INFORMATION ABOUT THE EFFECTS AND RISKS OF SAI FOR LOCAL DECISION SUPPORT, ESPECIALLY FOR EXTREME EVENTS LIKE FLOODS, DROUGHTS, HEAT WAVES, AND SEVERE STORMS. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO USE DYNAMICAL DOWNSCALING TO SIMULATE SAI AT 3 KM RESOLUTION TO LEARN (1) HOW EXTREME EVENTS MIGHT CHANGE OVER THE 21ST CENTURY UNDER SAI; (2) THE ADDED VALUE OF DYNAMICAL DOWNSCALING OF SAI, PARTICULARLY FOR REPRESENTING EXTREME EVENTS, OVER THE U.S. MIDWEST AND THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS; (3) BEST PRACTICES FOR PORTING THE DYNAMICAL DOWNSCALING METHODOLOGY TO OTHER REGIONS; AND (4) WHICH METHOD OF REPRESENTING SAI BEST REPRESENTS COMPLEX AEROSOL MICROPHYSICS. THE PROPOSED WORK AIMS TO BUIL

STRATOSPHERIC AEROSOL INTERVENTION (SAI) HAS BEEN PROPOSED TO REDUCE SOME OF THE EFFECTS OF FUTURE CLIMATE CHANGE. TO UNDERSTAND THE FULL RANGE OF SAI IMPACTS ON THE CLIMATE SYSTEM, COMPREHENSIVE EARTH SYSTEM MODELS ARE NEEDED TO SIMULATE VARIOUS PROCESSES AND FEEDBACKS AFFECTED BY SUCH APPLICATIONS. HOWEVER, THERE ARE LARGE UNCERTAINTIES IN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPACTS AND RISKS OF DIFFERENT SAI METHODS. NCAR IS DEVELOPING A VERSION OF THE CESM2 EARTH SYSTEM MODEL THAT INCLUDES THE OPTION TO COUPLE THE ATMOSPHERIC MODEL WITH THE COMMUNITY AEROSOL AND RADIATION MODEL FOR ATMOSPHERES (CARMA) FRAMEWORK, WHICH INCLUDES A MORE SOPHISTICATED SIZE-RESOLVING AEROSOL MODEL, AS A REPLACEMENT FOR A SIMPLER MODAL AEROSOL MODEL (MAM). THE FUNDAMENTAL SCIENCE QUESTION BEHIND MARINE CLOUD BRIGHTENING (MCB) AS A CLIMATE INTERVENTION MECHANISM IS WHETHER THE REFLECTIVITY OF MARINE BOUNDARY LAYER CLOUDS CAN BE DELIBERATELY INCREASED IN A CONTROLLED MANNER BY RELEASING AEROSOL PARTICLES INTO THE MARINE BOUNDARY LAYER IN TARGETED REGIONS. THE PROPOSED WORK FOCUSES ON QUANTIFYING THE FULL RANGE OF CLOUD RESPONSES IN METEOROLOGICAL REGIMES UNDER WHICH MCB MIGHT BE IMPLEMENTED, USING REALISTIC BACKGROUND AND INJECTED AEROSOL CONFIGURATIONS. THIS IS DONE THROUGH TWO MODELING STUDIES USING A LARGE EDDY SIMULATION MODEL. THESE MODEL STUDIES ARE DESIGNED TO (A) ESTABLISH THE FIDELITY OF THE MODEL IN SIMULATING THE EVOLUTION OF LOW MARINE CLOUDS, ABSENT PERTURBATION ('BASELINE' TESTS) AND (B) SYSTEMATICALLY EXPLORE HOW LOW MARINE CLOUDS RESPOND TO REALISTIC MCB AEROSOL INJECTION SCHEMES FOR THE RANGE OF METEOROLOGICAL AND BACKGROUND AEROSOL CONDITIONS PRESENT IN THE AMBIENT ENVIRONMENT IN LIKELY TARGET REGIONS ('PERTURBATION STUDI

ONE OF THE PRIMARY SOLAR CLIMATE INTERVENTION STRATEGIES UNDER CONSIDERATION IS STRATOSPHERIC AEROSOL INJECTION (SAI). SAI WOULD INCREASE THE NUMBER OF SMALL REFLECTIVE PARTICLES (AEROSOLS) IN THE UPPER ATMOSPHERE TO COOL THE CLIMATE BY REFLECTING MORE INCOMING SOLAR RADIATION AWAY FROM EARTH. THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE ENSEMBLE CONVECTION-PERMITTING REGIONAL SIMULATIONS OF CONVECTIVE STORMS OVER THE CONTIGUOUS UNITED STATES (CONUS) DRIVEN BY LARGE ENSEMBLES OF CLIMATE MODEL SIMULATIONS IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE THREE GOALS: (1) DETERMINE HOW THE IMPACTS OF SOLAR CLIMATE INTERVENTION MIGHT INFLUENCE THE OCCURRENCE, FREQUENCY, AND STRUCTURE OF CONVECTIVE STORMS; (2) QUANTIFY THE RANGE OF UNCERTAINTIES ASSOCIATED WITH INTERNAL VARIABILITY AND DIFFERENT FORCING SCENARIOS ON THE ENVIRONMENTS SUPPORTING CONVECTIVE STORMS; AND (3) PROVIDE A THOROUGHLY TESTED AND EVALUATED HIGH-RESOLUTION CONVECTION-PERMITTING FUTURE CLIMATE ENSEMBLE DATASET WITH AND WITHOUT SOLAR CLIMATE INTERVENTION FOR THE ATMOSP

LOCATED IN THE ARID SOUTHWEST, WATER IS A REVERED RESOURCE FOR THE PUEBLO DE SAN ILDEFONSO, AND CENTRAL TO MANY CULTURAL PRACTICES AND ESSENTIAL NEEDS. DROUGHT AND OTHER CHANGES IN HYDROLOGICAL CYCLES AFFECTS INFILTRATION RATES AND RECHARGE TO GROUNDWATER AQUIFERS, WHICH ADVERSELY AFFECTS SURFACE WATER BODIES SUSTAINED BY GROUNDWATER, INCLUDING SPRINGS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO PROTECT SPRINGS LOCATED ON THE PUEBLO DE SAN ILDEFONSO FROM DROUGHT TO HELP SUSTAIN WILDLIFE AND NATIVE VEGETATION, WHILE ALSO ENSURING THE PUEBLO COMMUNITY CAN VISIT AND USE THE SPRINGS, PARTICULARLY SACRED SITES, FOR TRADITIONAL AND CULTURAL PRACTICES. THE PROJECT WILL RESTORE AREAS DIRECTLY SURROUNDING SPRINGS ON PUEBLO LANDS, COLLABORATE WITH SURROUNDING LANDOWNERS TO IDENTIFY GROUNDWATER RECHARGE AREAS AT HIGHER ELEVATIONS THAT REPLENISH SPRINGS AND ASSESS THE NEED TO ENHANCE OR PROTECT THESE RECHARGE AREAS. MONITORING AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT WILL BE AN INTEGRAL PART OF THIS PROJECT, INCLUDING MONITO

THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE KARUK TRIBE AIMS TO IMPROVE KARUK SOCIO-ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE TO DROUGHT BY 1) INCREASING ACCESS TO DROUGHT-RELEVANT DATA FOR KARUK TRIBAL MANAGERS AS WELL AS B) INCREASING KARUK COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT IN RESEARCH, MONITORING, AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES TO BETTER INTEGRATE INDIGENOUS AND WESTERN SCIENCE AND MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS AND ACHIEVE MORE RAPID AWARENESS OF AND RESPONSE TO DROUGHT IMPACTS ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE. CENTRAL APPALACHIA IS A GEOGRAPHICALLY AND SOCIOLOGICALLY COMPLEX REGION WHERE MANY COMMUNITIES ARE ISOLATED FROM ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, BUT NOT ENVIRONMENTAL RISKS. THOUGH APPALACHIAN COMMUNITIES ARE CHARACTERIZED BY CLOSE INTERPERSONAL RELATIONSHIPS AND COMMITMENT TO THEIR LANDSCAPE, PREDICTED EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, MOST NOTABLY FLOODING, WILL CHALLENGE THEIR RESILIENCE IN UNPRECEDENTED WAYS. OVER THE PAST 75 YEARS, A QUARTER OF FEDERAL DISASTER FLOOD EVENTS HAVE BEEN IN APPALACHIA. UNDER ANTICIPATED CLIMATE CHANGE PREDICTIONS, THIS TREND WILL CONTINUE, WITH HEALTH AND ECONOMIC IMPACTS EXACERBATED BY OUTDATED, UNDERFUNDED INFRASTRUCTURE, HIGH POVERTY, AGEING POPULATIONS, AND EXISTING HEALTH DISPARITIES. NAVIGATING THESE INTERTWINED CHALLENGES GROUNDED IN A FOUNDATION OF STRONG COMMUNITY DEVOTION TO FAMILY AND PLACE, APPALACHIA CAN OFFER STRATEGIES FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES TO SUCCEED IN THE FACE OF ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE. WETLANDS MITIGATE THE IMPACTS OF DROUGHT BY ABSORBING AND RETAINING EXCESS WATER DURING WET PERIODS AND RETURNING IT TO THE WATER TABLE DURING DRY PERIODS. EVEN THOUGH 65% OF THE WETLANDS ONCE FOUND WITHIN THE COEUR D'ALENE INDIAN RESERVATION HAVE BEEN LOST, THE CULTURAL, ECOLOGICAL, AND SPIRITUAL IMPORTANCE OF WETLAND FUNCTIONS REMAIN SACRED TO THE COEUR D'ALENE PEOPLE. IN ORDER TO BUILD TRIBAL CAPACITY AROUND DROUGHT RESILIENCE, WE WILL INTEGRATE TRIBAL KNOWLEDGE AND WETLAND SCIENCE THROUGH SIX RESTORATION PROJECTS. THE RESULTING RESTORED WETLANDS WILL INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF WETLANDS TO MITIGATE DROUGHT; PROVIDE HABITAT FOR CULTURALLY IMPORTANT PLANTS, FISH, AND WILDLIFE; AND ENHANCE CULTURAL SERVICES. WE WILL ALSO IMPLEMENT A "WETLANDS TO COMBAT DROUGHT MONITORING PROGRAM" TO EVALUATE HOW WETLANDS HELP LESSEN THE EFFECTS OF DROUGHT OVER TIME.

MOBILE HOME PARK COMMUNITIES ARE COMMONLY FOUND IN RURAL AND EX-URBAN AREAS IN THE UPPER NORTHEAST REGION, AND IN PARTICULAR THE NORTHERN NEW ENGLAND STATES OF MAINE, NEW HAMPSHIRE, AND VERMONT. THESE COMMUNITIES ARE IDENTIFIED AS FRONTLINE COMMUNITIES THAT ARE ESPECIALLY VULNERABLE TO CLIMATE-RELATED EXTREME EVENTS. DEVELOPING A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THESE UNIQUE, UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES ARE BEING IMPACTED BY CLIMATE CHANGE REQUIRES A FOCUSED EFFORT TO ENGAGE KEY STAKEHOLDERS AND LEVERAGE LOCAL EXPERTISE WHILE ENHANCING NETWORKS WITHIN AND ACROSS THE THREE STATES.  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROOF-OF-CONCEPT PLANNING PROPOSAL IS TO EXPLORE THE CLIMATE-RELATED VULNERABILITIES OF MOBILE HOME PARK FRONTLINE COMMUNITIES. PAST WORK IN THE STATE OF VERMONT SERVES AS THE BASIS FOR DEEPER, USER-INSPIRED RESEARCH TO BE CO-PRODUCED WITH PARK RESIDENTS. WHAT WE LEARN FROM RECENT DROUGHT EXPERIENCES CAN HELP REDUCE THE SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS OF FUTURE DROUGHTS. ONE OF THE CHALLENGES IS IN CONNECTING SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH WITH RANCHERS AND OTHER LAND MANAGERS WHOSE DAY-TO-DAY DECISIONS DETERMINE HOW THE NEXT DROUGHT WILL AFFECT NOT JUST THEIR OWN HERDS, BUT THE COMPLEX ECOSYSTEMS THAT SUPPORT CATTLE AND MANY OTHER SPECIES. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL INCORPORATE DATA AND OBSERVATIONS FROM ON-THE-GROUND DECISION-MAKERS, USING STATE-OF-THE ART TECHNOLOGY, INCLUDING REMOTE SENSING AND MACHINE LEARNING, TO BOIL DOWN VAST AMOUNTS OF DATA FOR EASIER USE. THE NEW "ECODRI" FRAMEWORK FOR DELIVERING INFORMATION WILL BE ROOTED IN THE NEEDS AND PREFERENCES OF USERS WITH BOOTS ON THE GROUND, ALLOWING THEM TO BOTH PROVIDE INFORMATION AND TO ACCESS STREAMS OF CLEARLY CONDENSED, RELEVANT DATA.

SALT MARSHES ARE USUALLY WET PLACES, COVERED WITH LOTS OF PLANTS. THEY ARE THREATENED BY CLIMATE CHANGE (SEA LEVEL RISE). WHEN PROJECTS REBUILD LANDSCAPES TO BRING LOST MARSHES BACK (RESTORATION), THE STARTING POINT IS A BARE LANDSCAPE. WITH NO PLANTS AND NO ROOTS TO HOLD IN MOISTURE AND PROVIDE SHADE, THE LANDSCAPE IS ALMOST LIKE A DESERT RATHER THAN A WETLAND. NEW SEEDLINGS HAVE DIFFICULTY GROWING IN THE DRY AND SALTY CONDITIONS. WE ARE LOOKING AT THE CAUSES OF PLANT DEATH AND TESTING WHETHER PROVIDING FRESHWATER WITH TEMPORARY SPRINKLERS CAN HELP JUMPSTART PLANT GROWTH AT RESTORATION SITES.

THE SOUTHWEST US IS EXPERIENCING MORE FREQUENT AND SEVERE DROUGHTS, LEADING TO UNPRECEDENTED DIE-OFFS OF FOUNDATIONAL PLANT SPECIES ACROSS ECOSYSTEMS. FOR NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBES, LOSS OR MOVEMENT OF PLANTS USED FOR FOOD, CEREMONIES, MEDICINE OR ART, IMPERILS CULTURAL PRACTICES AND TRADITIONAL LIFE WAYS TIED TO THOSE SPECIES. HERE, WE COMBINE INFORMATION ON SOCIAL CONNECTIONS TO NATURAL AREAS WITH ECOLOGICAL DATA, TO IDENTIFY ECOCULTURAL HOTSPOTS THAT ARE VULNERABLE TO DROUGHT. USING THIS INFORMATION, WE WILL IDENTIFY PRIORITY SITES FOR RESTORATION TREATMENTS THAT MITIGATE ECOCULTURAL LOSSES.

THERE IS A LACK OF PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATA THAT DESCRIBES CLIMATE ADAPTIVE CAPACITY IN RURAL COMMUNITIES IN THE UNITED STATES  FEW STUDIES HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED AND NONE WITH A NATIONAL  SCOPE. THIS SCIENTIFIC GAP CREATES ADDITIONAL CHALLENGES FOR RURAL COMMUNITIES ATTEMPTING TO  DEMONSTRATE THEIR FISCAL NEED FOR RESOURCES TO FUNDING AGENCIES. CONCURRENTLY, AGENCIES LACK DATA  TO MAKE MORE EQUITABLE FISCAL DECISIONS.   THE GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO DEVELOP A VALIDATED RURAL CLIMATE-ADAPTIVE-CAPACITY INDEX FOR THE  ENTIRE UNITED STATES AND DISPLAY THE RESULTS IN AN ONLINE MAPPING TOOL WHILE ALSO CONTRIBUTING  INSIGHTS TO THE ACADEMIC LITERATURE.   THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILL USE A MIXED-METHODS APPROACH TO CALIBRATE AND VALIDATE AN INDEX OF  CLIMATE ADAPTIVE CAPACITY FOR RURAL COMMUNITIES, NOTING THAT SOCIAL VULNERABILITY AND ADAPTIVE  CAPACITY ARE NOT SYNONYMOUS. THIS PROPOSAL IS AIMED AT A SYSTEMATIC ASSESSMENT OF THE CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES RELATED TO  CLEAN ENERGY INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENTS IN THE RURAL COMMUNITIES OF THE U.S. BY LEVERAGING THE PI'S  PAST AND ONGOING RESEARCH ON CLEAN ENERGY POLICY ANALYSIS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL/ENERGY JUSTICE, THIS  PROPOSAL SEEKS TO ADDRESS SEVERAL IMPORTANT KNOWLEDGE GAPS, INCLUDING THE JUSTICE IMPLICATIONS OF  CLEAN ENERGY TRANSITION FOR RURAL COMMUNITIES, THE EFFECTIVENESS AND DISTRIBUTIONAL IMPACTS OF LOCAL  WIND ENERGY ORDINANCES, AND THE INNOVATIVE CLIMATE ADAPTATION FINANCING MECHANISM. RESULTS OF  THIS PROJECT ARE EXPECTED TO HELP POLICY MAKERS AND ACTIVISTS UNDERSTAND INEQUALITIES ASSOCIATED WITH CLIMATE ADAPTATION INVESTMENTS IN ENERGY SYSTEMS, AND TO ENABLE EVIDENCE-BASED POLICY  MAKING. THE GOAL IS TO SUPPORT AND STRENGTHEN THE CAPACITY OF RURAL GOVERNMENTS TO DESIGN AND  IMPLEMENT PUBLIC POLICIES THAT PROMOTE AND FUND EQUITABLE AND SUSTAINABLE CLIMATE ADAPTATION  STRATEGIES. THIS PROPOSAL DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS AC4 COMPETITION BY QUANTIFYING FIRE EMISSIONS AND RESULTING CHANGES TO AIR QUALITY IN THE WUI USING MODELING TOOLS, SATELLITE DATA, AND FIELD CAMPAIGN DATA. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE NEW INSIGHTS INTO THE CHEMISTRY OF WILDFIRE SMOKE AS IT AGES AND INTERACTS WITH PEOPLE IN URBAN AND RURAL COMMUNITIES AND PROVIDE NEW INFORMATION ON HOW REDUCTIONS IN CONTROLLABLE ANTHROPOGENIC NOX EMISSIONS COULD CHANGE THE CHEMISTRY AND HUMAN HEALTH IMPACTS OF SMOKE. IT WILL ALSO PROVIDE BETTER TOOLS TO QUANTIFY SMOKE IMPACTS IN URBAN, RURAL AND SUBURBAN REGIONS. THIS PROJECT IS DIRECTLY RELEVANT TO NOAA-CPOS, AC4 PRIORITIES IN THAT WE WILL: 1. ADVANCE KNOWLEDGE OF SMOKE CHEMISTRY AND O3 PRODUCTION IN URBAN AND RURAL AREAS AND IN THE WILDLAND-URBAN INTERFACE. 2. UTILIZE NOAA RESOURCES (AIRCRAFT AND SATELLITE DATA). 3. IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPACTS OF SMOKE ON URBAN PHOTOCHEMISTRY AND AIR QUALITY, HELPING US UNDERSTAND THE HUMAN IMPACTS ON MILLIONS OF PEOPLE. 4. IMPROVE QUANTIFICATION OF THE IMPACTS OF SMOKE ON URBAN O3, PROVIDING SUPPORT AND A BETTER UNDERSTANDING FOR STATES TO DEVELOP EXCEPTIONAL EVENT REQUESTS. 5. BY UNDERSTANDING THE NOX-VOC

THE PROPOSED WORK WILL APPLY A SUITE OF NEW SPACE-BASED VOC RETRIEVALS FROM THE CROSS-TRACK INFRARED SOUNDER (CRIS) TO BETTER UNDERSTAND FIRE EMISSIONS AND THEIR ATMOSPHERIC IMPACTS. THESE NEXT-GENERATION RETRIEVALS EXPLOIT THE CRIS LOW NOISE AND DENSE SAMPLING, EMPLOYING A MACHINE-LEARNING APPROACH THAT COMBINES HIGH SENSITIVITY WITH REDUCED IMPACTS FROM INTERFERENCES AND FORWARD MODEL ERRORS. THE RESEARCH ADDRESSES CORE PRIORITIES OF THIS AC4 SOLICITATION: APPLICATION OF JPSS SATELLITE PRODUCTS TO STUDY BIOMASS BURNING; AND RESEARCH PUTTING FIREX-AQ DATA IN A LARGER CONTEXT. RESULTS WILL SUPPORT ONGOING NOAA FIRE-RELATED ACTIVITIES BY PROVIDING NEW CONSTRAINTS FOR EVALUATING AND IMPROVING: 1) THE GBBEPX (GLOBAL BIOMASS BURNING EMISSIONS PRODUCT EXTENDED) SYSTEM AT NESDIS; AND 2) THE REPRESENTATION OF FIRE AND FIRE EMISSIONS IN GFDL ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY (AM4.1) AND EARTH SYSTEM (ESM4.1) MODELS. THIS WORK WILL BE CARRIED OUT IN UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA.

THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EXPLORE HOW WILDFIRE EMISSIONS, WHEN MIXED WITH ANTHROPOGENIC EMISSIONS, AFFECT THE O3-NOX-VOC CHEMISTRY OVER DOWNWIND URBAN AREAS IN CALIFORNIA. THE PROPOSED STUDY WILL EXPLOIT EMERGING NEW-GENERATION SATELLITE OBSERVATIONS (TROPOMI, CRIS, MODIS), THE WEALTH OF IN SITU MEASUREMENTS FROM RECENT FIELD CAMPAIGNS (WE-CAN AND FIREX-AQ) AND GROUND-BASED MONITORING NETWORKS, A HIERARCHY OF MODELS FROM SIMPLE BOX MODEL TO METEOROLOGY-CHEMISTRY MODEL, TO TRACK THE EVOLUTION O3 PRECURSORS (NOX AND VOCS) FROM FIRES, INVESTIGATE THE RADIATIVE AND CHEMICAL EFFECTS OF FIRE SMOKE ON O3 CHEMISTRY, AND ANALYZE THEIR VARIATIONS WITH FIRE (I.E., FUEL TYPE, FIRE INTENSITY, INJECTION HEIGHT, COMBUSTION EFFICIENCY). THIS PROPOSED WORK WILL BUILD ON PREVIOUS WORK SUPPORTED BY NOAA THAT SHOWS THE PROMISE OF USING TROPOMI NO2 TO PROVIDE DIRECT ESTIMATES OF NOX EMISSIONS AND LIFETIMES.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO PERFORM MOLECULAR CHARACTERIZATION OF THE CHEMICAL COMPOSITION OF ORGANIC AEROSOL SAMPLES COLLECTED DURING PLANNED EXPERIMENTS AT THE NIST-NFRL TEST FACILITY AT GAITHESBURG, MD SIMULATING SMOKE EMISSIONS IN THE WILDLAND-URBAN INTERFACE FIRE EVENTS.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO PERFORM MOLECULAR CHARACTERIZATION OF THE CHEMICAL COMPOSITION OF ORGANIC AEROSOL SAMPLES COLLECTED DURING PLANNED EXPERIMENTS AT THE NIST-NFRL TEST FACILITY AT GAITHESBURG, MD SIMULATING SMOKE EMISSIONS IN THE WILDLAND-URBAN INTERFACE FIRE EVENTS.

THE PROPOSED WORK WILL LEVERAGE A MULTITUDE OF PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATASETS TO PLACE THE FIREX-AQ DATA INTO A BROADER CONTEXT THROUGH STATISTICAL MODELING, AND IT WILL APPLY THESE STATISTICAL MODELS IN THE INTERPRETATION OF JPSS (AND OTHER) SATELLITE PRODUCTS. THESE EFFORTS ADDRESS THE OVERALL MISSION OF NOAA "TO UNDERSTAND AND PREDICT CHANGES IN CLIMATE, WEATHER, OCEANS, AND COASTS" BY PROVIDING AN IMPROVED METHOD TO PROCESS DATA USED IN THE EVALUATION OF CHEMISTRY-CLIMATE MODELS, AND THEREFORE, ALSO SUPPORTS NOAA'S LONG-TERM GOAL TOWARDS CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION. THIS WORK WOULD BE CARRIED OUT IN OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY.

THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO ADVANCE THE INCLUSION OF BLUE CARBON ECOSYSTEMS IN NATIONAL GREENHOUSE GAS INVENTORIES IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES. COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS SUCH AS MANGROVES, SALT MARSHES AND SEA GRASSES CAPTURE AND STORE ATMOSPHERIC CARBON AT A HIGHLY EFFICIENT RATE, ACTING AS A CARBON SINK.  WHILE THESE SYSTEMS ARE SMALLER IN GEOGRAPHICAL SCOPE THAN THE WORLDS FORESTS, THEY TAKE UP CARBON FROM THE ATMOSPHERE AT A FASTER RATE, AND CAN STORE IT FOR MILLIONS OF YEARS IF THEY ARE UNDISTURBED. THE ABILITY OF THESE ECOSYSTEMS TO SEQUESTER (OR CAPTURE) AND STORE CARBON IS KNOWN AS COASTAL BLUE CARBON. COUNTRIES AROUND THE WORLD ARE INCREASINGLY LOOKING TO COASTAL BLUE CARBON ECOSYSTEMS AS A NATURE-BASED CLIMATE SOLUTION THAT OFFERS BENEFITS FOR MITIGATING AND ADAPTING TO CLIMATE CHANGE, AS WELL AS FOR THE BENEFITS THEY PROVIDE FOR STORM SURGE PROTECTION, FISHERIES AND TOURISM. THIS WORK WILL USE MULTIPLE ATMOSPHERIC REANALYSIS AND IN SITU STATION DATASETS TO CREATE A NORTH AMERICAN PRODUCT FOR EXCESS TEMPERATURE AND RELATIVE EXCESS TEMPERATURE (INCORPORATING HUMIDITY, WIND, SEASONALITY AND GEOGRAPHY) EVENTS INCLUDING INFORMATION ON FREQUENCY, DURATION, SPATIAL EXTENT, AND POPULATIONS IMPACTED BY THESE EVENTS. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL USE THE IN SITU STATIONS TO VALIDATE THE REANALYSIS DERIVED HEAT STRESS INDICES, AND WILL EVALUATE TRENDS AS WELL AS REGIONAL AND SEASONALITY CHARACTERISTICS. HAVING DEVELOPED THOSE INDICES THE TEAM WILL COLLABORATE WITH NOAA TO TRANSITION THIS PRODUCT TO NCEI AND WILL SET-UP A WEB-BASED REAL-TIME FORECASTING SYSTEM DRIVEN BY NOAA SEASONAL FORECASTS.

THIS PROPOSAL PRESENTED WORK TO ADDRESS THE CURRENT LACK OF HIGH RESOLUTION COASTAL WATER LEVEL INFORMATION, ONE APPLICATION OF WHICH WOULD BE TO PUT FUTURE REGIONAL SEA LEVEL RISE PROJECTIONS INTO CONTEXT, BY GENERATING AND VALIDATING A NEW COASTAL WATER LEVEL REANALYSIS THAT IS GEOSPATIALLY AND TEMPORALLY CONSISTENT AT HIGH RESOLUTION.

THE PROPOSED WORK WILL DEVELOP A NEW SMOKE AND WILDFIRE MONITORING PRODUCT THAT ADVANCES CURRENT INFORMATION ABOUT SMOKE HAZARDS AND CAN BE POTENTIALLY USEFUL TO SCIENTISTS AND DECISION MAKERS. IT WILL HELP TO DETERMINE THE MOST VULNERABLE TO BURNING REGIONS DUE TO STEADY ACCUMULATION OF FUEL OVER THE 20TH CENTURY.  WITH THE CHEMICAL TRANSPORT MODEL GEOS-CHEM, IT WILL COMBINE WIND AND SMOKE DATA TO DIAGNOSE REGIONS WHERE POTENTIAL FIRES COULD LEAD TO THE GREATEST NUMBER OF PEOPLE EXPERIENCING SMOKE EXPOSURE DOWNWIND. THE PROPOSED WORK APPLIES A DYNAMIC VEGETATION MODEL (LPJ-LMFIRE) TO PINPOINT THOSE REGIONS THAT ARE CURRENTLY EXPERIENCING THE GREATEST FIRE DEFICIT AND THIS CAN POTENTIALLY HELP GUIDE FIRE AND LAND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND MAY HELP TO CHANGE PUBLIC OPINION ABOUT PRESCRIBED BURNING. USING THIS KNOWLEDGE TOGETHER WITH INFORMATION ON THOSE REGIONS WHERE THE SMOKE POTENTIAL FIRES COULD AFFECT LARGE NUMBERS OF PEOPLE, A SMOKE RISK INDEX PRODUCT WILL BE CONSTRUCTED. THIS PR

THIS PROPOSAL INTENDS TO PRODUCE HUMAN HEAT STRESS METRICS BACK TO 1895, PRIMARILY USING DATA FROM NCEIS GLOBAL HISTORICAL CLIMATOLOGY NETWORK-HOURLY (GHCNH).  STATION TIME SERIES WITH SUFFICIENT DATA DURING THE RECORD WILL BE USED FOR STUDIES OF LONG-TERM TRENDS, VARIABILITY, AND EVENT CASE STUDIES.  THE TWENTIETH CENTURY REANALYSIS VERSION 3 (20CRV3) WILL BE USED TO FILL IN ANY MISSING DATA, AND WILL ALSO BE USED TO INVESTIGATE SYNOPTIC-SCALE FEATURES OF HEAT EVENTS.  THE LONGER PERIOD OF ANALYSIS WILL ENABLE STUDY OF HEAT WAVES DURING THE 1930S AS COMPARED TO CURRENT YEARS.

AS SEA LEVELS RISE OVER THE NEXT DECADES, COASTAL FLOODING WILL HAVE INCREASED IMPACTS ON BUILT, SOCIETAL, AND NATURAL SYSTEMS. THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSAL IS TO MONITOR SEA LEVEL VARIABILITY FOR THE ENTIRE US COAST, AND THE PROPOSERS AIM AT DEVELOPING A MONITORING NEAR-REAL TIME (~ ONE MONTH) PRODUCT FOR TRACKING AND UNDERSTANDING DAILY, MONTHLY AND EXTREMES IN COASTAL SEA LEVEL. THEY WILL EXPAND ON AN ALREADY EXISTING WEB PRODUCT BY DEVELOPING SUMMARY STATISTICS, CHARACTERIZING SEA LEVELS. THEY WILL CATALOG AND CONTEXTUALIZE CHARACTERISTICS USING SHORE-BASED TIDE GAUGES, SATELLITE-BASED ALTIMETRY OBSERVATIONS, AND REANALYSIS/ANALYSIS PRODUCTS. THEY ALSO PLAN TO DIAGNOSE PHYSICAL CONTRIBUTIONS SUCH AS LONG-TERM TRENDS, OCEANIC VARIABILITY, AND ATMOSPHERIC CONDITIONS. THE PIS ALSO PROPOSE TO DETERMINE WHAT MODES OF WEATHER AND CLIMATE VARIABILITY EXPLAIN SEA LEVEL ANOMALIES AS THEY ARE OCCURRING, UTILIZING ASSESSMENTS OF STATED OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC MODEL ANALYSES.

THE PROPOSAL IS TITLED, "DEVELOPMENT OF A COMPREHENSIVE FLASH DROUGHT MONITORING FRAMEWORK" BY JASON OTKIN AND TRENT FORD WITH COLLABORATIONS AT NOAA CPC, PSL, AND NDMC. THEY WILL DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE FLASH DROUGHT MONITORING FRAMEWORK THAT COMBINES INFORMATION FROM MULTIPLE DATASETS REVEALING ANOMALIES IN PRECIPITATION, EVAPORATIVE DEMAND, SOIL MOISTURE AND VEGETATION HEALTH.  A FLASH DROUGHT INTENSITY INDEX (FDII) WILL BE DEPLOYED TO BETTER REPRESENT FLASH DROUGHT.  A FRAMEWORK WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR AN OPTIMAL FDII AND FOR THIS TO BE AVAILABLE TO NDMC AND THE DROUGHT MONITOR.

VARIOUS TREND MAPS WILL BE PRODUCED TO THE COUNTY SCALE AND METROPOLITAN STATISTICAL AREAS, WITH A FOCUS ON URBAN AREAS. THE REAL-TIME HVI MONITOR WOULD HAVE 4-5 DISTINCT AND PLAINLY-NAMED CATEGORIES AND WOULD BE DEVELOPED FOR THE ENTIRE REGION AT THE COUNTY-LEVEL. THE PRIMARY AIM OF THESE WORKSHOPS AND ASSOCIATED ACTIVITIES IS TO ADVANCE SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING AND PREDICTABILITY OF EARTH SYSTEMS THROUGH LEARNING AND COLLABORATION ACROSS DISCIPLINARY BOUNDARIES. AGCI APPLIES A TIME-TESTED APPROACH TO CONVENING THAT AFFORDS HIGH-CALIBER SCIENTIFIC DISCUSSION WHILE AT THE SAME TIME BROADENING PARTICIPATION AND FOSTERING INCLUSIVE RESEARCH CULTURES. OUTCOMES FROM WORKSHOPS SHARE NEW FINDINGS AND CONCEPTS WITH LARGER COMMUNITIES, CATALYZE NEW RESEARCH INITIATIVES, BUILD CAPACITY WITHIN EXISTING RESEARCH PROGRAMS, SUPPORT THE MISSIONS OF FEDERAL AGENCIES AND OTHER SPONSORS, AND ENGAGE THE PUBLIC ON THE RELEVANCE AND POTENTIAL USES OF SCIENCE REGARDING GLOBAL CHANGE.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP MEAN DYNAMIC SEA LEVEL (MDSL) DIAGNOSTICS NEAR COASTLINES TO ASSESS, PRIORITIZE AND IMPROVE KEY UNDERLYING PROCESSES FOR SEA LEVEL RISE SIMULATIONS AND PROJECTIONS BY CLIMATE MODELS. TO ACHIEVE THE GOAL, THE PI WILL USE ALTIMETER- AND TIDE-GAUGE-BASED MDSL REFERENCE PRODUCTS TO ASSESS THE REPRESENTATION OF COASTAL MDSL IN A HIERARCHY OF GFDL OCEAN AND CLIMATE MODELS, AND IDENTIFY THE KEY PROCESSES RESPONSIBLE FOR MDSL BIASES IN MODEL SIMULATIONS. THE OUTCOME OF THE PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE MDTF ANALYSIS PACKAGE THAT CAN BE APPLIED TO ANALYZE OTHER CMIP6 MODELS. OVERALL, THE PANEL FOUND THIS PROPOSAL INTERESTING. SOME ASPECTS COULD BE FURTHER IMPROVED. WITH THE PERMISSION OF AVAILABLE FUNDS AND COMPETITION, THE PROJECT IS WORTHY OF SUPPORT.

PROJECT TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF RESILIENT HARVEST-CONTROL RULES IN RESPONSE TO CLIMATE IMPACTS ON FISH STOCK PRODUCTIVITY. THIS PROPOSAL IS SUBMITTED TO THE COCA FISHERIES AND CLIMATE PROGRAM COMPETITION 8: UNDERSTANDING CLIMATE IMPACTS ON FISH STOCKS AND FISHERIES TO INFORM SUSTAINABLE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT. STATEMENT OF THE PROBLEM: CLIMATE IS A DOMINANT DRIVER OF FISH POPULATION DYNAMICS AND WHILE SUBSTANTIAL WORK HAS BEEN CONDUCTED ON THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE, INTEGRATING THIS INFORMATION INTO MANAGEMENT HAS BEEN LIMITED. MEANWHILE, ANNUAL CATCH LIMITS MUST BE SET FOR MANY STOCKS THAT ARE THOUGHT TO BE IMPACTED BY CLIMATE, BUT WITHOUT A MECHANISM FOR INCORPORATING CLIMATE INFORMATION. THEREFORE, AN APPROACH IS NEEDED TO IDENTIFY HARVEST-CONTROL RULES THAT ARE RESILIENT TO CLIMATE-INDUCED CHANGES IN PRODUCTIVITY AND THAT CAN BE APPLIED ACROSS A BROAD SET OF STOCKS.
